Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE FUNDS PROVIDED THROUGH THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM WILL BE UTILIZED TO STRENGTHEN THE LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEM BY PROCURING LOCAL PRODUCT FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS/PRODUCERS FIRST AND FOREMOST. THE NARRAGANSETT INDIAN TRIBE WILL THEN DISTRIBUTE PRODUCT TO ITS MEMBERSHIP VIA DESIGNATED DISTRIBUTION DATES AND SITES. THE NARRAGANSETT INDIAN TRIBE WILL SUBCONTRACT WITH BRANDON FAMILY FARMS, EAST FARM COMMERCIAL FISHERIES CENTER, THE NARRAGANSETT TRIBAL FARM, AND SEVERAL ADDITIONAL LOCAL DISADVANTAGED FARMS AND FOOD PRODUCERS TO MEET THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES, IN UNISON WITH THE OVERALL GOALS OF THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. SUPPORT LOCAL DISADVANTAGED FOOD PRODUCERS ECONOMICALLY BY PROVIDING SAID FOOD PRODUCERS WITH DIRECT PAYMENTS (TOTALING $300,000, APPROXIMATELY 62.5% OF TOTAL AWARD) TO PURCHASE THEIR RESPECTIVE PRODUCT. FACILITATE BRIDGE OF DISTRIBUTION BETWEEN UNDERSERVED NARRAGANSETT TRIBAL COMMUNITY AND LOCAL PRODUCERS FOR THE INTENT OF DISTRIBUTING FRESH PRODUCT VIA ACQUISITION, ASSEMBLAGE, AND DISTRIBUTION TO ABOVEMENTIONED UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY. RECORD, ANALYZE, AND DISTRIBUTE COLLECTED DATA AS IT PERTAINS TO PROGRAM OUTCOMES, GOALS AND OBJECTIVES MET, UP TO AND INCLUDING POSITIVE AFFECTS WITHIN THE LOCALLY SOURCED AND CONTRACTED FOOD PRODUCER COMMUNITY. OUTLINE ANY NEW OPPORTUNITIES CREATED THROUGH THE PROGRAM AND PROVIDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY AND BEST PRACTICES. UTILIZE THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM INVESTMENT IN ALIGNMENT WITH LOCAL PRODUCERS TO BEST REPLICATE THE TRADITIONAL DIET OF THE NARRAGANSETT INDIAN TRIBE, INCLUSIVE OF FRESH SEAFOOD, VEGETABLES, FRUITS, AND GRAIN. UTILIZE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM INVESTMENT TO IMPLEMENT A PILOT PROGRAM WHICH WILL INDEPENDENTLY CONTRACT EXPERIENCED NARRAGANSETT TRIBAL MEMBERS FOR THE PURPOSE OF SOURCING LOCAL VEGETATION, FISH, AND WILDLIFE VIA FORAGING, FISHING, AND HUNTING. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE PROGRAM WILL ENHANCE AND IMPROVE LOCAL FOOD DISTRIBUTOR VIABILITY, WHILE ALSO ENHANCING THE SAFETY AND SECURITY OF THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY SUBCONTRACTING DIRECTLY WITH FRESH FOOD DISTRIBUTORS FOR THE GROWING, HARVESTING, PACKAGING, AND DELIVERY OF THEIR RESPECTIVE FOOD. NARRAGANSETT INDIAN TRIBE’S SOURCING, ASSEMBLAGE, AND DISTRIBUTION OF FRESH FOOD FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED LOCAL PRODUCERS TO FEED THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY IN NEED PROGRAM WILL CONTRACT AND SOURCE DIRECTLY WITH FARMS AND FOOD PRODUCERS. BENEFICIARIES ON THE PRODUCER SIDE SHALL INCLUDE 20 LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND FOOD PRODUCERS, BOTH FARM FRESH AND SEAFOOD, WITH FOCUS GIVEN ON THOSE FARMS AND FOOD PRODUCERS THAT MEET THE CRITERIA FOR BEING CONSIDERED SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO LOCAL FARMERS AND FOOD SUPPLIERS TO IMPLEMENT ALL ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH MEETING THE OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM PROJECT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL ENABLE MEMBERS OF THE RED CLIFF TRIBAL COMMUNITY TO BUILD ON EXISTING OFFERINGS BY SOURCING LOCAL, HEALTHY FOODS OF THEIR PREFERENCE THROUGH A FOOD VOUCHER PROGRAM DEVELOPED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS AND HARVESTERS. THE BAYFIELD SCHOOL WILL RECEIVE A SUBAWARD FROM THE FARM (AS THE ENTITY MANAGING THIS PROJECT), ALONG WITH A CONTRACT THAT OUTLINES THE OPTIONS AND PROCEDURES FOR PROCURING THESE FOODS FROM RED CLIFF WITHIN THE SPECIFIC PARAMETERS ESTABLISHED BY THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FUNDS WILL PROVIDE A SIGNIFICANT BOOST TO THE COMMUNITY’S ACCESS TO AND DEMAND FOR SUCH FOODS, THEREBY ADVANCING RED CLIFF’S FOOD SOVEREIGNTY GOALS IN A WAY THAT IS BOTH PURPOSEFUL AND SUSTAINABLE. MINO BIMAADIZIIWIN TRIBAL FARM AND RED CLIFF FISH COMPANY ARE THE MAIN PRODUCERS THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROGRAM. BOTH ARE RED CLIFF-OWNED AND OPERATED ENTERPRISES. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO MINO BIMAADIZIIWIN FARM AND RED CLIFF FISH COMPANY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS FOR THE MENOMINEE NATION WILL COORDINATE THE PROCUREMENT OF INDIGENOUS FOODS ON BEHALF OF THE ONEIDA NATION, RED CLIFF BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA, STOCKBRIDGE-MUNSEE BAND OF MOHICAN INDIANS, HO-CHUNK NATION, FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI, SOKAOGON CHIPPEWA COMMUNITY, BAD RIVER BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA, AND THE GERALD L. IGNACE INDIAN HEALTH CENTER FOR THE TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOX PROGRAM. THE INTERTRIBAL FOOD SYSTEM TEAM WILL CONSIST OF MEMBERS FROM EACH OF THE 9 PARTICIPATING TRIBES AND ONE INTERTRIBAL URBAN COMMUNITY, PARTNERED WITH THE SHARED GOAL OF GETTING FOOD TO OUR WIDER TRIBAL COMMUNITIES USING THE TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOX PROGRAM AS A MODEL. ONE BOX WILL BE DISTRIBUTED PER HOUSEHOLD WITH A TRIBAL ELDER. THE RECIPIENTS WE INTEND TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE MEMBERS OF ALL TRIBAL HOUSEHOLDS RECEIVING THE TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOX, THROUGHOUT EACH OF THE PARTICIPATING TRIBES. UPON REACHING OVER 900 TRIBAL HOMES MONTHLY WITH APPROXIMATELY 10,800 FOOD BOXES ANNUALLY, WE EXPECT THAT NUMBER GROW FROM 900 TO 1600, AND THE TOTAL BOXES TO GO FROM 10,800 TO 24,000. THE INTERTRIBAL FOOD PROGRAM BEGAN WITH 24 PARTNERS WHICH INCLUDES THOSE CONTRACTED AND TRIBES PARTICIPATING. OUR PARTNERSHIPS HAVE SINCE EXPANDED UP TO 30 AN INCREASE OF 6 ADDITIONAL PARTNERS. WE PREDICT THAT 100% OF THOSE ADDITIONAL PARTNERSHIPS WILL CONTINUE BEYOND THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROGRAM. THE FOLLOWING ITEMS BUILD A FOUNDATION FOR AN INTERTRIBAL FOOD SYSTEM TO INCREASE AND SUPPORT THE NUMBER OF NATIVE PRODUCERS; EXPAND THE SOURCE AND DISTRIBUTION OF TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOXES TO ADDITIONAL NATIVE NATIONS AND OFFER COMMUNITY FOOD BOXES TO TRIBAL MEMBERS BEYOND ELDERS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE MENOMINEE INDIAN TRIBE PLANS TO SOURCE FOODS DIRECTLY FROM TRIBAL AGRICULTURAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED BLACK INDIGENOUS PEOPLE OF COLOR PRODUCERS WITHIN THE GREAT LAKES REGION. THE ONEIDA NATION APPLE ORCHARD HAS 20 ACRES OF ORIGINAL ORCHARD AND AN ADDITIONAL 10 ACRES OF NEW ORCHARD WHICH NOW TOTALS APPROXIMATELY 4,000 TREES. THE RED CLIFF FISH CO. PROVIDES LAKE SUPERIOR WHITEFISH RICH IN PROTEIN VITAMINS MINERALS AND OMEGA-3S MORE EVEN THAN IN PINK AND SOCKEYE SALMON. SPIRIT LAKE NATIVE FARMS SUPPLY WILD RICE AND CHIPPEWA VALLEY PRODUCE SOURCES FROM HMONG GROWERS, GROWERS FOR WHICH NONE OF THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT AGRICULTURE PROCUREMENT GRANT FUNDS HAVE YET REACHED. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO FEEDING WISCONSIN FOR SPECIAL PROGRAMS AND LOGISTICS TO IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIES ASSOCIATED WITH MEETING THE OBJECTIVES OUTLINED IN THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROJECT.

THE LET’S GROW ARIZONA LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FOR ARIZONA WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH A STRENGTHS-BASED THREE-TIERED APPROACH BY THE ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY, WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH THE ARIZONA FOOD BANK NETWORK AND PINNACLE P REVENTION. THIS WILL INCLUDE ENGAGING LOCAL PRODUCERS THROUGH DIRECT MARKET OUTLETS AND FOCUSING ON DISTRIBUTION AMONG LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS WITHIN LOCAL MUNICIPALITIES, ENGAGING LOCAL PRODUCERS THROUGH REGIONAL COLLABORATION EFFORTS THAT WILL SCALE REGIONAL INNO VATIONS THAT SURFACED AMID THE PANDEMIC, AND ENGAGING LOCAL PRODUCERS THROUGH EXPANSION OF THE FRIENDS OF THE FARM EFFORTS, WHICH IS A FARM-TO-FOOD BANK PROGRAM OFFERING INSTITUTIONAL PURCHASING AND DISTRIBUTION POWER. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDING FOR ARIZONA WILL BE IMPLEMENTED THROUGH A STRENGTHS-BASED APPROACH LEVERAGING CURRENT EFFORTS UNDERWAY THAT ARE EXPANDING LOCAL FOOD CONSUMPTION AMONG LOW-INCOME INDIVIDUALS WHILE ALSO SERVING AS AN OPPORTUNITY TO EXPLORE A TIERED APPROACH TO ENTRY FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS THAT BOTH MEETS FARMERS WHERE THEY ARE AT WHILE ALSO EXPANDING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES ACROSS MULTIPLE CHANNELS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY WILL ESTABLISH 140 NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES BY PURCHASING FROM LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS AND IT IS EXPECTED THAT 20 PERCENT WILL BE SUSTAINED AFTER FUNDING IS EXPENDED. ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY WILL ESTABLISH 100 NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES BY PURCHASING FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS AND IT IS EXPECTED THAT 20 PERCENT WILL BE SUSTAINED AFTER FUNDING IS EXPENDED. ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY WILL ESTABLISH 10 NEW FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS TO SERVE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND IT IS EXPECTED THAT 20 PERCENT WILL BE SUSTAINED AFTER FUNDING IS EXPENDED. ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY WILL DISSEMINATE PROJECT PROGRESS AND RESULTS MONTHLY TO THE STATE NUTRITION ACTION COMMITTEE AND QUARTERLY PROGRESS AND RESULTS TO THE HUNGER ADVISORY COUNCIL AND THROUGH ARIZONA FOOD SYSTEMS NETWORK. ANNUAL PROJECT REPORTS WILL REACH APPROXIMATELY 250 STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE STATE. ADDITIONALLY, THE ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF ECONOMIC SECURITY WILL COMPILE AND SHARE PROJECT EVALUATION OUTCOMES WITH 250 STAKEHOLDERS TO INFORM ONGOING SCALE AND EXPANSION OPPORTUNITIES. THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM PRESENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO INCREASE OUR REACH FURTHER AMONG SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS BY EXPANDING THE TYPES OF LOCAL FOOD OPTIONS THAT CAN BE PURCHASED AND DISTRIBUTED AMONG UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND THE PATHWAYS BY WHICH CONSUMERS CAN CONNECT WITH THEIR LOCAL PRODUCERS. IT IS PROJECTED THAT THIS PROJECT WILL REACH AT LEAST 10,000 UNDERSERVED INDIVIDUALS IN AT LEAST 10 COUNTIES BY THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO THE ARIZONA FOOD BANK NETWORK AND PINNACLE PREVENTION.

THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY, A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBE, WILL UTILIZE THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT GRANT TO DISTRIBUTE APPROXIMATELY 4,500 FOOD BOXES TO NATIVE AMERICANS IN FOREST COUNTY, WISCONSIN, AND SURROUNDING COUNTIES. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT ADDITIONAL FOOD DISTRIBUTIONS TO TRIBAL ELDERS THROUGH FEEDING WISCONSIN’S TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOX PROGRAM. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. TO IMPLEMENT THE PROJECT, FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BODWÉWADMI KTËGAN, A SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FOOD PRODUCER, TO PACKAGE, PURCHASE, AND DISTRIBUTE MONTHLY FOOD BOXES TO FOUR DISTRIBUTION POINTS WITHIN THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT AIMS TO SUPPORT NATIVE AMERICAN FAMILIES IN NORTHERN WISCONSIN WHO ARE STRUGGLING WITH THE RISING COST OF FOOD AND STRIVES TO STRENGTHEN TRIBAL FOOD SOVEREIGNTY AND SECURITY BY EXPANDING CAPACITY AT BODWÉWADMI KTËGAN. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY EXPECTS THIS FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM TO BENEFIT AT LEAST 105 TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS.  FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY WILL UTILIZE AT LEAST 20 PE RCENT OF THE GRANT FUNDS TO SUPPORT FEEDING WISCONSIN’S TRIBAL ELDER FOOD BOX PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES TRIBAL ELDERS IN WISCONSIN WITH PERISHABLE FOOD ON A BIWEEKLY BASIS. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO ADDRESS FOOD INSECURITY IN A 7 COUNTY AREA OF NORTHWEST LOWER MICHIGAN (ANTRIM, GRAND TRAVERSE, BENZIE, LEELANAU, CHARLEVOIX, MANISTEE AND KALKASKA). THIS PARTNERSHIP WILL PURCHASE FOOD FROM LOCAL PRODUCERS AND DISTRIBUTE IT THROUGH A NETWORK OF OVER 70 FOOD PANTRIES, MEAL SITES AND BABY PANTRIES; 3 OF WHICH ARE OPERATED BY GRAND TRAVERSE BAND. THE GOAL IS TO ADDRESS FOOD INSECURITY AND SUPPORT LOCAL PRODUCERS WHILE PROVIDING FRESH FOOD TO THE COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN NEED. THIS INITIATIVE SEEKS TO BOLSTER REGIONAL FOOD PRODUCTION EFFORTS BY ESTABLISHING CRITICAL FIRST SALE CONNECTIONS BETWEEN LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS AND THE NETWORK OF PARTNERS AT THE NORTHWEST FOOD COALITION AND THE REGIONS LARGEST EMPLOYER, GRAND TRAVERSE BAND. THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE GRANT ALLOWS FOR GRAND TRAVERSE BAND TO ONCE AGAIN PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN THE REGIONAL FOOD NETWORK. OPERATING THREE FOOD PANTRIES IN A NETWORK OF 70 FOOD PANTRIES REGIONALLY. AT LEAST 30 LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS WOULD PARTICIPATE. THESE PRODUCERS RANGE FROM SMALL SCALE FARMS OPERATED BY SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS (GRAND TRAVERSE BAND FARM AND FISHERIES) TO MICHIGAN - FARM COOPERATIVE THAT AGGREGATE FOOD PRODUCTS FROM MULTIPLE FARMS TO STREAMLINE DISTRIBUTION. FORMING THESE CONNECTIONS CREATES AN OPPORTUNITY FOR GRAND TRAVERSE BAND TO BE A LEADER IN LOCAL FOOD PURCHASING. THE PRIMARY SUBPOPULATION THAT WILL BE SERVED BY THIS PROJECT INCLUDE FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS WHO GET THEIR FOOD FROM FOOD PANTRIES, MEAL SITES, COMMUNITY MENTAL HEALTH CENTERS, BABY PANTRIES, AND SCHOOL FOOD PANTRIES. WITH THIS FUNDING, THE NORTHWEST FOOD COALITION WILL SEE A 40 PERCENT INCREASE IN THE DOLLAR AMOUNT GOING TOWARD THE PURCHASE OF LOCAL FOOD TO BE DISTRIBUTED TO ITS MEMBER FOOD PANTRIES, BABY PANTRIES AND MEAL SITES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE AGRICULTURE DEPARTMENT DOES A MONTHLY REPORT ON PROJECTS TO THE TRIBAL MANAGERS OFFICE. WORKING CLOSELY WITH THE PARTNERS AND STAKE HOLDERS OF THIS PROJECT THE AGRICULTURE MANAGER WILL ADDRESS WHAT IS WORKING AND NOT WORKING THROUGH FOOD DISTRIBUTION. THE TEAM WILL WORK TOGETHER TO DEVELOP A REPORT THAT HIGHLIGHTS THE SUCCESSFUL EXECUTION ON THE PROJECT AND SHOW HOW SOLUTIONS WERE DEVELOPED WHEN PROBLEMS AROSE. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO GOODWILL NORTHERN MICHIGAN FOR FOOD RESCUE PURCHASE AND HANDLING, GROUNDWORK FOR FOOD PURCHASING AND HANDLING, AND NORTHWEST MICHIGAN COMMUNITY ACTION AGENCY, NORTHWEST FOOD COALITION FOR FOOD PURCHASING AND HANDLING.

BISHOP PAIUTE TRIBE’S MUADUBU NUUMU FRESH PRODUCE PROGRAM UNDER THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE GRANT WILL PROVIDE FRESH HEALTHY PRODUCE TO THE BISHOP PAIUTE TRIBAL ELDERS PROGRAM AND TO ADDITIONAL TRIBAL MEMBERS FROM THIS UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY WHO NEED FOOD. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE PROGRAM WILL PROCURE FRESH FRUIT AND VEGETABLE BOX SUBSCRIPTIONS FROM PRODUCERS. BOXES WILL BE DELIVERED TO THE RESERVATION AT LEAST TWICE A MONTH OVER A ONE-YEAR PERIOD AND DISTRIBUTED AT ONE OF TWO LOCATIONS WITH HOME DELIVERY TO THE HOMEBOUND AND DISABLED. THE FOOD BOXES WILL INCLUDE RECIPES FOR THE PRODUCE AND STORAGE DIRECTIONS. THE PROGRAM IS EXPECTED TO ALLEVIATE HUNGER AND INCREASE HEALTH BY LOWERING INCIDENCES OF DIABETES AND CARDIOVASCULAR DISORDER. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE PROGRAM WILL BENEFIT TWO TO FOUR PRODUCERS, INCLUDING SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED LOCAL PRODUCERS. THE PROGRAM WILL BENEFIT 200 TRIBAL ELDERS OVER THE AGE OF 55 AND 200 TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN NEED OF FOOD. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.  THE PURPOSE OF THE MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS PRODUCE PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM IS TO PURCHASE FRESH PRODUCE FROM CHOCTAW FRESH PRODUCE; TO DISTRIBUTE HEALTHFUL, FRESH PRODUCE TO ALL OF MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS COMMUNITIES, TARGETING THE UNDERSERVED; AND TO MAXIMIZE PROGRAM OUTCOMES BY UTILIZING COMMUNITY-BASED MARKETING AND OUTREACH METHODS/ACTIVITIES. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDING WILL ENABLE MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS TO PURCHASE FRESH FOOD FROM CHOCTAW FRESH PRODUCE 16 HIGH-TUNNEL ORGANIC FARM. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDING WILL ENABLE MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS TO DISTRIBUTE THIS PRODUCE TO ALL 8 MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS COMMUNITIES THROUGH OPERATION OF A MOBILE MARKET AND A DIRECT DELIVERY SYSTEM TO BENEFICIARIES. A COMMUNITY-BASED MARKETING OUTREACH PLAN WILL BE DEVELOPED AND IMPLEMENTED TO EXPAND PROGRAM PARTICIPATION AT THE RECIPIENT LEVEL ACROSS TRIBAL LANDS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. LOCALLY-PRODUCED HEALTHFUL, FRESH PRODUCE WILL BE PROVIDED TO APPROXIMATELY 11,000 TRIBAL MEMBERS ANNUALLY, TARGETING THE UNDERSERVED, OVER THE TWO-YEAR PROJECT PERIOD. RECIPIENTS WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE ALL APPROXIMATELY 11,000 MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS TRIBAL MEMBERS. AT LEAST TWELVE (12) SPECIFIC TRIBAL PROGRAMS WILL RECEIVE PRODUCE PURCHASED FROM CHOCTAW FRESH PRODUCE. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS (ADMINISTRATION, FOOD PRODUCERS/STORAGE, FOOD DISTRIBUTORS AND RECIPIENTS) ARE TRIBAL MEMBERS AND ARE DEFINED AS SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED. PROGRAM RECIPIENTS/BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE ALL TRIBAL MEMBERS THROUGH DIRECT FOOD DISTRIBUTION TO 8 TRIBAL COMMUNITY CENTERS, AN ELDERLY ACTIVITY CENTER AND 3 MISSISSIPPI BAND OF CHOCTAW INDIANS HEALTH CENTER PROGRAMS.

THE COLUMBIA RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISH COMMISSION WILL UTILIZE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM GRANT FUNDS TO DEVELOP AND STRUCTURE A FOOD DELIVERY SYSTEM TO PROVIDE HEALTHIER FOOD TO UNDERSERVED AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED TRIBAL COMMUNITIES AT THEIR RESPECTIVE RESERVATIONS AND ALONG THE COLUMBIA RIVER. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE PROJECT WILL INVOLVE PURCHASING FRESH, NUTRITIOUS, SEASONAL VEGETABLES, FRUITS, AND FISH PRODUCTS. IT WILL INVOLVE COORDINATION BETWEEN THE FOUR MEMBER TRIBES, THE COLUMBIA RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISH COMMISSION, A FISH PROCESSING VENDOR, AND A TRIBALLY OWNED FARM TO PROVIDE FOR THE DELIVERY OF FOOD BOXES, INCLUDING FRESH VEGETABLES, FRUITS, AND FISH. THE PROJECT WILL PURCHASE FISH PRODUCTS, E.G., CANS, POSSIBLY FILLETS IN YEAR 2, FROM BORNSTEIN SEAFOODS, AN EXPERIENCED SEAFOOD PROCESSOR. THE PROCESSOR WILL PURCHASE SALMON HARVESTED BY TRIBAL FISHERS FOR INCLUSION INTO VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS, WHICH WILL BE PURCHASED BY COLUMBIA RIVER INTER-TRIBAL FISH COMMISSION FOR DISTRIBUTION. THE PROJECT WILL HELP RE-ESTABLISH TRIBAL TRADE ROUTES AND COMMUNICATION SYSTEMS TO BUILD UPON FOOD SOVEREIGNTY EFFORTS AND LOOK FOR WAYS TO IMPROVE THE CHOICES AND DIETS OF TRIBAL MEMBERS THROUGH FOOD ALTERNATIVES ALIGNED WITH TRADITIONAL DIETS AND ACCESS TO FRESH AND NUTRITIOUS FOODS. CONTRACTING WITH VENDORS AND SUBAWARDEES WILL INCREASE LOCAL FOOD CONSUMPTION AND HELP BUILD AND EXPAND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY FOR LOCAL SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS AND TRIBAL FISHERS BY PROVIDING ACCESS TO THESE FOODS, AS PEOPLE CAN TASTE, EAT, AND DEVELOP PREFERENCES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETINGOPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. TWO PRODUCERS, YAKAMA NATION FARMS, A NATIVE-OWNED FARM, AND BORNSTEIN SEAFOODS WILL BENEFIT FROM THIS PROJECT. APPROXIMATELY 50 TRIBAL FISHERS WILL PROVIDE SALMON FOR THE CANNED PRODUCTS WHICH WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITIES BOTH ALONG THE COLUMBIA RIVER AND TO THE RESERVATION COMMUNITIES. IT IS ESTIMATED THAT BETWEEN 3,247 AND 4 ,329 TRIBAL MEMBERS, WHICH INCLUDES INDIVIDUALS LIVING ALONG THE COLUMBIA RIVER, WILL BE THE RECIPIENTS AND BENEFICIARIES FOR THE DISTRIBUTION OF THESE FOODS AS UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND AS COMMUNITIES NOT NORMALLY SERVED THROUGH TRADITIONAL FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO NEZ PERCE TRIBE, CONFEDERATED TRIBES AND BAND OF THE YAKAMA NATION, CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE UMATILLA INDIAN RESERVATION, AND CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE WARM SPRINGS RESERVATION.

THE SPIRIT LAKE TRIBE INTENDS TO PROCURE AND DISTRIBUTE DOMESTIC AND TRIBAL GROWN FOOD TO AN UNDERSERVED AND IMPOVERISHED COMMUNITY WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. SPIRIT LAKE TRIBE’S GOAL IS TO PROCURE HEALTHY-READY TO EAT, FROZEN MEALS THAT INCLUDE TRADITIONAL FOODS FROM A TRIBAL OWNED VENDOR TOCABE MARKETPLACE. THE SOURCE OF THE FOODS FOR THE MEALS WILL BE SOURCED FROM TRIBAL COMMUNITIES THAT ARE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED AND ALLOW NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PRODUCERS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. OUR GOAL IS TO ESTABLISH A NEW MARKETING SYSTEM FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS FOR NO LESS THAN 6 TRIBAL VENDORS TO PROCURE FOODS FOR TOCABE MARKETPLACE TO PREPARE MEALS FOR DISTRIBUTION. WE ALSO HOPE TO EXPAND A NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITY FOR A TRIBAL VENDOR TO MARKET TRADITIONAL FOODS PROCURED FR OM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED VENDORS WITH A STEADY MARKET THAT CAN BE SUSTAINABLE. OUR FINAL GOAL IS TO DISTRIBUTE A TRADITIONAL AND HEALTHY FOOD SOURCE FOR FAMILIES AND ELDERLY FAMILIES WHO WILL BENEFIT FROM A HEALTHIER FOOD SOURCE THAT IS ACCESSIBLE TO THEIR HOMES THROUGH FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAMS AND SENIOR SERVICES DELIVERY MECHANISM. THE SPIRIT LAKE TRIBE WILL DISTRIBUTE 1,024 TRADITIONAL MEALS PER MONTH FOR 24 MONTHS TO THE LOW-INCOME FAMILIES ON THE SPIRIT LAKE RESERVATION. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO TOCABE MARKETPLACE.

THE LOCAL FOOD PROCUREMENT PROJECT WILL SUPPLEMENT EXISTING NUTRITIONAL SUPPORT PROGRAMS, SUCH AS THE TITLE VI ELDER’S NUTRITION PROGRAM, THE YUROK TRIBE FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS PROGRAM, AND THE ELDER’S FISHERY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THIS PROJECT WILL PURCHASE FOOD FROM AN ESTIMATED 150 PRODUCERS, THE MAJORITY OF WHICH BEING YUROK PRODUCERS, AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TO TRIBAL MEMBERS. TRADITIONAL FOODS WILL BE THE HIGHEST PRIORITY FOR PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTION, FOLLOWED BY OTHER APPLICABLE FOODS FROM INDIGENOUS PRODUCERS, OTHER BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR PRODUCERS, AND OTHER LOCAL PRODUCERS RESPECTIVELY. WITH THE PURCHASING PRIORITIES OF THIS PROJECT PRIORITIZING YUROK FOOD PRODUCERS, WE WILL SUPPORT SMALL BUSINESSES RELATED TO THE PROCUREMENT AND PROCESSING OF TRADITIONAL FOODS, SMALL-SCALE FRUIT AND VEGETABLE GROWERS, AND FLEDGLING FOOD-RELATED GARDENS AND NURSERIES OPERATED BY THE YUROK TRIBE AND AFFILIATED CORPORATIONS. PRIORITIZING PURCHASING FROM YUROK PRODUCERS WILL HELP ADDRESS FINANCIAL INSECURITY IN HOUSE HOLDS BY PROVIDING TWO YEARS OF A CUSTOMER WITH A LARGE PURCHASING CAPACITY. IDEALLY, THIS FUNDING WILL ALLOW PRODUCERS TO BUILD UPON THESE EARLY SUCCESSES TO EXPAND THEIR ABILITY TO PRODUCE AND DISTRIBUTE THEIR PRODUCTS TO A WIDER MARKET. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE RE PORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. WE ANTICIPATE PURCHASING FOOD FROM LOCAL PRODUCERS, 125 OF WHICH ARE YUROK TRIBAL MEMBERS. WHILE WE WILL PRIORITIZE THE 250 HOUSEHOLDS WITHIN THE YUROK INDIAN RESERVATION FIRST FOR RECEIVING FOOD, WE WILL BE DISTRIBUTING FOOD THROUGHOUT ALL SEVEN DISTRICTS OF THE YUROK TRIBE. WE ANTICIPATE REACHING AT LEAST 400 HOUSEHOLDS DURING THIS PROJECT. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT THE BAD RIVER TRIBE’S LOCAL FOOD PURCHASING AGREEMENT PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO PROVIDE LOW INCOME TRIBAL MEMBERS WITH ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY, LOCALLY SOURCED FOOD, INCLUDING INDIGENOUS FOODS PRODUCED IN THE GREAT LAKES REGION.  THE PROCUREMENT OF LOCAL FOODS FROM OTHER PROGRAMS THE TRIBAL ELDER AND COMMUNITY FOOD BOX PROGRAM, VENDORS SUPPLYING BADGER BOXES FOR THE HUNGER TASK FORCE, AND FROM TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL FOOD PRODUCERS IN THE CHEQUAMEGON BAY AREA AND WITHIN 300 MILES OF THE BAD RIVER RESERVATION. BAD RIVER FOOD DISTRIBUTION ALREADY HAS VALUED PARTNERS WITH INTRA-GOVERNMENTAL DEPARTMENTS SUCH AS THE BAD RIVER ENROLLMENT DEPARTMENT, BAD RIVER HOUSING, BAD RIVER FOOD SOVEREIGNTY PROGRAM, AND BAD RIVER’S HEAD START, YOUTH, ELDERLY AND FEEDING PROGRAMS. THESE DEPARTMENTS’ REFERRALS TO OUR PROGRAMS HELP US IDENTIFY HIGHEST NEED PARTICIPANTS, SOME WHOM MAY ONLY NEED TEMPORARY ASSISTANCE AND OTHERS WHO ARE IN CHRONIC SITUATIONS OF FOOD INSECURITY. WE PROJECT AN AVERAGE OF 150 LOW-INCOME TRIBAL FAMILIES MONTHLY. DURING THE WARMER MONTHS THESE NUMBERS WILL LIKELY REACH OVER 200. THE UNITED STATED DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PARTNERSHIP WILL ALLOW THE TRIBE TO EXPAND ELIGIBILITY BEYOND ELDERS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO HEALTHY, LOCAL AND CULTURALLY SPECIFIC FOODS TO YOUNGER TRIBAL FAMILIES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. SOURCING FOOD FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS, SUCH AS TRIBAL NEIGHBORS WHO COMMERCIALLY FISH FOR LAKE SUPERIOR WHITEFISH AND OGAA (WALLEYE), OUR OWN FOOD SOVEREIGNTY PROGRAM GRADUATES WHO ARE NOW SMALL SCALE DIVERSIFIED VEGETABLE GROWERS OR FORAGERS OF WILD GROWN PRODUCE, BENEFITS FOOD PRODUCERS AS WELL AS THE RECIPIENTS OF FOOD BOXES. THESE PRODUCERS HAVE NEVER BEEN ABLE TO PA RTICIPATE IN LARGE SCALE FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS WHETHER SUBSIDIZED OR ON THE OPEN MARKET. THIS IS A KEY NEW TARGET AUDIENCE WHO WILL BE ASSISTED THROUGH THIS PROGRAM.

THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH INTENDS TO USE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE (LFPA) FUNDS TO ESTABLISH A PROGRAM THAT ENABLES THE PURCHASE OF LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTS FROM DISADVANTAGED FARMERS ACROSS THE STATE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THOSE PRODUCTS TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FUNDING WILL BE USED TO IMPROVE LOCAL SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY BY INCREASING MARKET OPPORTUNITIES FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND INCREASING THE QUALITY AND NUTRITIONAL CONTENT OF FOOD DISTRIBUTED BY FOOD PANTRIES AND OTHER ORGANIZATIONS. THIS FUNDING WILL ADDRESS EXISTING NEEDS IN BOTH UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND AMONG LOCAL PRODUCERS. THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL ADMINISTER MOST LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE GRANT FUNDS TO SUB-AWARDEES THROUGH A COMPETITIVE RFP PROCESS AVAILABLE TO TEFAP AND NON-TEFAP AFFILIATED FOOD PANTRIES, NONPROFITS, LOCAL AGGREGATORS, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT AGENCIES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARK ETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH EXPECTS TO INCREASE MARKET OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL, DISADVANTAGED FOOD PRODUCERS WHILE INCREASING LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTS DISTRIBUTED TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES EXPERIENCING FOOD INSECURITY. ADDITIONALLY, WE WILL CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR LEARNING ABOUT PROGRAM SUCCESSES AND CHALLENGES WHICH WILL IN TURN INCREASE THE USE OF INNOVATIVE METHODS OF SOURCING AND DISTRIBUTING LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTS. THE UTAH DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH ESTIMATES THAT APPROXIMATELY 30 ADDITIONAL PRODUCERS WILL BE ADDED TO REGULAR FOOD DISTRIBUTION IN UTAH, WITH 75% BEING DISADVANTAGED. THIS PROGRAM WILL SUPPORT DISTRIBUTION AT 20 LOCATIONS THAT SERVE VARYING NUMBERS OF INDIVIDUALS. ALL RECIPIENTS WILL BE MEMBERS OF AN UNDERSERVED POPULATION. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS THROUGH A COMPETITIVE REQUEST FOR PROPOSAL PROCESS OPEN FOR ALL COMMUNITY PARTNERS TO APPLY.

THE MONACAN INDIAN NATION WALUT PÍ:SE “FOOD IS GOOD” PROJECT, FUNDED BY THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM GRANT, AIMS TO ASSIST AND SUPPORT OUR LOCAL FARMERS AND VENDORS, PROVIDE GOOD, HEALTHY LOCAL FOODS TO OUR TRIBAL CITIZENS AND THE COMMUNITY AND TO PROVIDE FOR THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. CREATE PARTNERSHIPS WITH AT LEAST NINETEEN LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FOOD DISTRIBUTORS TO PURCHASE FOODS FOR DISTRIBUTION AND TO HELP BUILD AND EXPAND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES. THE GRANT WILL PROVIDE SUSTAINABILITY FOR THE NEXT TWO YEARS, INCREASE OUR CAPACITY AND EXPERIENCE, PAY EXISTING STAFF TO SUPPORT THEIR ONGOING EFFORTS, AND BUILD STRONGER RELATIONSHIPS WITH LOCAL VENDORS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. OUR TARGET CLIENTS ARE CITIZENS OF THE MONACAN INDIAN NATION, BUT OUR FOODBANK SERVES, AND WILL CONTINUE TO SERVE, OTHER SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS IN OUR SERVICE AREA AND LOW AND MODERATE INCOME FAMILIES OF OUR TRIBE AND IN OUR SERVICE AREA. WE WILL SERVE AT LEAST 425 FAMILIES THREE MEALS PER MONTH FOR A TOTAL OF 1300 SAFE, HEALTHY, AND LOCALLY-PRODUCED MEALS AND FOOD ITEMS PER MONTH TO THE UNDERSERVED MONACAN TRIBAL CITIZENS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PASCUA YAQUI TRIBE INTEND TO USE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDING TO PURCHASE FRESH FOOD PRODUCTS AND PRODUCE FROM LOCAL, SOCIALLY, AND HISTORICALLY, DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, AND RANCHERS TO FILL THE CURRENT GAPS IN THE TRIBE’S FOOD PANTRY AND MEAL OFFERINGS, WHILE EXPANDING NUTRITIONAL FOOD CONSUMPTION BY LOW-INCOME TRIBAL MEMBERS. THE TRIBE’S FOOD PROGRAMS WILL WORK IN COLLABORATION WITH THE SAN XAVIER FARM COOPERATIVE AND OTHER LOCAL AND REGIONAL, DISADVANTAGED FOOD PRODUCERS, TO PURCHASE THE TYPES OF FRESH FOODS THAT ARE REGULARLY REQUESTED BY A SUBSTANTIAL PART OF THE COMMUNITY INCLUDING, FRUITS, VEGETABLE, AND MEATS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE OVERALL GOALS OF THIS PROGRAM ARE TO PERFORM OUTREACH TO FIFTEEN LOCAL, SOCIALLY AND HISTORICALLY DISADVANTAGED FOOD PRODUCERS, AND FORM PURCHASING PARTNERSHIPS WITH SEVEN OR EIGHT PRODUCERS, INCREASE THE NUMBER OF HEALTHY MEALS TO LOW-INCOME FAMILIES BY AT LEAST ONE HUNDRED NINETY THREE PERCENT AND THE NUMBER OF UNDUPLICATED CLIENTS SERVED ANNUALLY BY AN ADDITIONAL ONE HUNDRED NINE CLIENTS. PROGRESS TOWARDS THESE GOALS WILL BE ASSESSED BY CONDUCTING JOINT STAFF MEETINGS AMONG THE THREE PROGRAMS AT LEAST SIX TIMES A YEAR TO SHARE EVALUATION DATA AND ENSURE THAT CLIENTS ARE USING ONE FOOD DELIVERY PROGRAM AND THEREBY MITIGATE FRAUD. THE INTENDED BENEFICIARIES OF THIS PROGRAM ARE THE TWENTY-TWO THOUSAND ENROLLED MEMBERS OF THE PASCUA YAQUI TRIBE. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE FARM TO CONSUMER FOOD INITIATIVE WILLPURCHASE CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE FOOD FROM REGIONAL FARMERS, WITH A FOCUSON THOSE OPERATED BY INDIGENOUS PEOPLE AND NEARBY TRIBAL NATIONS OVER ATWO-YEAR PERIOD. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE ANDDISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDFARMERS AND RANCHERS. LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE PLANS TO ENTERPURCHASING AGREEMENTS WITH AT LEAST FIVE PRODUCERS, THREE OF WHICH WOULDBE OPERATED BY NATIVE AMERICANS. THE CHOSEN PRODUCERS WILL BE ENCOURAGEDTO PARTNER WITH THE TRIBE IN DEVELOPING A LOCAL FARMING CURRICULUM.DISTRIBUTION WILL OCCUR THROUGH THE LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE ELDERLYNUTRITION PROGRAM, COMMUNITY CENTERS, AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A FOODBACKPACK PROGRAM AT AREA SCHOOLS. LEECH LAKE BAND OF OJIBWE IS IN THEBEGINNING STAGES OF CREATING A LOCAL NATIVE FOOD SYSTEM. THE CONTINUEDINTRODUCTION OF DIRECT FARM TO MARKET FOOD INTO THE COMMUNITY WILL HELPGAIN INTEREST IN DEVELOPING A LOCAL SYSTEM. PRODUCERS WILL BENEFIT BYGIVING FARMERS A NEW MARKET FOR THEIR PRODUCTS, WHILE ALSO GAINING ABETTER UNDERSTANDING OF NATIVE AMERICAN FOOD CULTURE. QUARTERLYPERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OFPRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTIONSITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACHCATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETINGOPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTIONNETWORKS. THE FOOD WILL BE USED TO PROVIDE FOOD TO LOW-INCOME TRIBALMEMBERS IN AREAS IDENTIFIED AS A FOOD DESERT OR THOSE KNOWN TO BECHRONICALLY NUTRITIONALLY INSECURE. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TOSUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA SEEKS TO EXPAND PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND COMMUNITY BASED ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE FREE, DIRECT FOOD DISTRIBUTION TO UNDERSERVED RESIDENTS FACING FOOD INSECURITY IN WARDS 7 AND 8. IN ADDITION, FUNDING WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE PRODUCE PLUS PROGRAM, OPERATED BY FRESHFARM, TO OFFER HOME DELIVERY OF PRODUCE TO HOMEBOUND RESIDENTS ENROLLED IN THE COMMODITY SUPPLEMENTAL FOOD PROGRAM. THE DISTRICT WILL UTILIZE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDS TO IMPROVE LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SUPPLY CHAIN CONNECTIONS FOR LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS TO RESIDENTS BY PARTNERING WITH TWO EQUITABLE FOOD ACCESS PROGRAMS. NUTRITIOUS, LOCAL FOODS PROCURED FROM LOCAL FARMERS AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO HELP MEET THE NEEDS OF UNDERSERVED DISTRICT RESIDENTS BY ENHANCING AND EXPANDING JOYFUL FOOD MARKETS, OPERATED BY MARTHA’S TABLE, AND PRODUCE PLUS, OPERATED BY FRESHFARM. JOYFUL FOOD MARKETS ARE MONTHLY, NO-COST GROCERY MARKETS THAT SUPPORT UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR AT OVER 50 SCHOOLS IN WARDS 7 AND 8, WHERE ONLY THREE FULL SERVICE GROCERY STORES ARE AVAILABLE TO 150,000 RESIDENTS. TO ADDRESS HEALTHY FOOD ACCESS BARRIERS OF TIME, TRANSPORTATION, AND COST, JOYFUL FOOD MARKETS ARE HELD AFTER SCHOOL DURING DISMISSAL TO SERVE AS CONVENIENT ACCESS POINTS FOR BUSY FAMILIES AND CAREGIVERS. THE DISTRICT WILL ALSO PARTNER WITH FRESHFARM, A LOCAL FARMERS’ MARKET OPERATOR AND LOCAL FOOD HUB, TO SUPPORT HOME-DELIVERY OF FREE PRODUCE BOXES THROUGH THE PRODUCE PLUS PROGRAM, FOR RESIDENTS WITH LOW-INCOMES FROM UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PROCURE PRODUCE FOR JOYFUL FOOD MARKETS AND PRODUCE PLUS THROUGH DREAMING OUT LOUD, A NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION SERVING LOCAL SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. IN ADDITION TO SUPPORTING THESE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, THESE PURCHASES ARE STRATEGIC INVESTMENTS THAT WILL CREATE GROWTH AND NEW ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS. BY PROVIDING A SUBSIDIZED PATHWAY TO NEW MARKET OPPORTUNITIES FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS, THIS PROJECT WILL NOT ONLY CONNECT UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES WITH CULTURALLY RELEVANT FOODS, BUT BUILD WEALTH WITHIN THESE COMMUNITIES. MARTHA’S TABLE AND JOYFUL FOOD MARKETS ARE POP-UP MONTHLY MARKETS HELD IN 53 ELEMENTARY SCHOOLS IN WARDS 7 AND 8 IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. FRESHFARM’S PRODUCE PLUS PROGRAM OFFER HOME DELIVERY OF PRODUCE TO HOMEBOUND RESIDENTS ENROLLED IN THE COMMODITY SUPPLEMENTAL FOOD PROGRAM. PARTICIPANTS RECEIVE A PRE-SELECTED BUNDLE OF PRODUCE DELIVERED TO THEIR HOME MONTHLY AT NO COST TO THE PARTICIPANT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOODTARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.WITH FUNDING PROVIDED BY THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE,AGRICULTURAL MARKETING SERVICE LOCAL FOODS PURCHASING AGREEMENT, THEFOND DU LAC BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA WILL ESTABLISH AANDANJIGEWIN,A FOOD DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM THAT WILL DECOLONIZE AND INDIGENIZE THE FONDDU LAC LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM, CREATE MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITYMEMBERS WHO HARVEST, PRODUCE, AND PROCESS FOOD PRODUCTS, INCREASE THEAVAILABILITY OF NOURISHING AND CULTURALLY TRADITIONAL FOOD TO COMMUNITYMEMBERS, BROADEN THE AWARENESS OF TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY AND TREATYHARVESTING RIGHTS BELONGING TO COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND ENCOURAGE BESTPRACTICES FOR SUSTAINABLE HARVEST, PREPARATION, AND PRESERVATION OFTRADITIONAL OJIBWE FOODS. TO CREATE STABLE AND VIABLE MARKETINGOPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL PRODUCERS, THE AANDANJIGEWIN LOCAL FOODSPURCHASING AGREEMENT PROGRAM WILL PURCHASE FOOD PRODUCTS DIRECTLY FROMUP TO 100 LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS AND HARVESTERS. THROUGH OUTREACH ANDEDUCATION, FOND DU LAC BAND MEMBERS WILL GAIN INCREASED AWARENESS OFTHEIR TREATY RIGHTS OF HARVEST, AS WELL AS KNOWLEDGE OF METHODS OFHARVESTING, PROCESSING, AND PRESERVING OJIBWE TRADITIONAL FOODS. THROUGHTHESE EFFORTS, THE FOND DU LAC BAND AIMS TO REDUCE FOOD INSECURITY,CREATE ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, REVITALIZE TRADITIONAL FOODWAYS, ADVOCATEFOR TRIBAL SOVEREIGNTY, EXPAND UNDERSTANDING OF TREATY RIGHTS WITHIN THECEDED TERRITORIES, AND FOSTER A DECOLONIZED LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM WITHIN THEFOND DU LAC COMMUNITY. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTEDTO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS ANDRANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDSEXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OFNEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENTFOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. TO INCREASE FOOD ACCESS, THESE FOOD PRODUCTSWILL THEN BE SHARED WITH THE COMMUNITY IN MULTIPLE DISTRIBUTIONS OF HALFTO THREE-QUARTER BUSHEL FOOD BOXES TO 500 FOND DU LAC HOUSEHOLDS ASSEASONAL HARVEST ALLOWS. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS AND ENHANCE THE WELL-BEING OF CHILDREN, THEIR FAMILIES AND THE STABILITY AND ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF THE COMMUNITIES WHERE THEY LIVE. THE MISSOURI DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SERVICES WILL ENTER INTO AGREEMENTS WITH MISSOURI FAMILY AND COMMUNITY TRUST PARTNERSHIPS TO PURCHASE FOOD. THE PARTNERSHIPS, EITHER THEMSELVES OR THROUGH SUBAWARD, WILL DEVELOP DISTRIBUTION MECHANISMS THAT TARGET AREAS THAT ARE NOT SERVICED BY EXISTING FOOD PANTRIES. THE PARTNERSHIP AGREEMENTS WILL OUTLINE REPORTING REQUIREMENTS ON ITEMS INCLUDING LISTINGS OF PURCHASES, THE QUANTITY PURCHASED, AND THE NAME OF WHOM THE ITEMS WERE PURCHASED FROM, IF THE FARMER/PRODUCER IS CONSIDERED SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED, DISTRIBUTION POINTS, CHALLENGES, SUCCESSES, AND COMMUNITY IMPACT. IN ADDITION, DSS WILL HAVE MONTHLY PHONE CALLS WITH THE PARTNERSHIPS TO DISCUSS THE PROJECT INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO CHALLENGES, SUCCESS, PARTNERSHIPS, AND COMMUNITY FEEDBACK. DSS WILL ALSO INVITE OTHER STAKEHOLDERS TO THE CALL. THESE CALLS WILL SERVE AS AN ONGOING DIALOGUE TO FOSTER RELATIONSHIPS, ASSIST AGENCIES AS THEY MITIGATE POTENTIAL CHALLENGES, AND ALLOW AGENCIES TO LEARN FROM OTHER AGENCIES AND IMPLEMENT BEST PRACTICES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. INITIAL STAKEHOLDERS HAVE BEEN IDENTIFIED; HOWEVER, THIS LIST WILL CONTINUE TO EXPAND TO POTENTIALLY INCLUDE EDUCATION SITES, ADDITIONAL COMMUNITY PARTNERS, PRODUCERS, AGGREGATORS, DISTRIBUTORS, AND OTHERS. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO MISSOURI FAMILY AND COMMUNITY TRUST.

JERSEY FRESH FOR ALL -THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM  WILL BUILD A STRONGER, FAIRER, AND MORE EQUITABLE NEW JERSEY BY PROVIDING THE FUNDS NECESSARY TO UNDERTAKE GROUNDBREAKING WORK IN OUR STATE. THIS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY INCREASING ACCESS TO LOCAL DOMESTIC FOOD AND IMPROVING AND MAINTAINING SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY BY BUILDING SUPPLIER PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL AND REGIONAL FARMERS AND RANCHERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, THROUGH SUBRECIPIENT AGENCY, THE COMMUNITY FOODBANK OF NEW JERSEY WILL DESIGN FOOD PURCHASING PROGRAMS AND ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS WITH FARMERS AND RANCHERS WITHIN THE STATE THAT BEST SUITS LOCAL NEEDS, ENVIRONMENTAL AND CLIMATE CONDITIONS, AND SEASONAL HARVESTS. THE COMMUNITY FOODBANK OF NEW JERSEY WILL COORDINATE WITH THE OTHER FOOD BANKS, FOOD BANK OF SOUTH JERSEY AND FULFILL, AS WELL AS ITS PARTNER DISTRIBUTION ORGANIZATIONS, MERCER STREET FRIENDS AND NORWESCAP, TO ENSURE THAT THE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS PURCHASED THROUGH THE GRANT REACH DISTRIBUTION POINTS IN ALL 21 COUNTIES. THE COMMON MARKET AND THE NEW JERSEY FOOD DEMOCRACY COLLABORATIVE WILL BE KEY COLLABORATORS IN THE RESEARCH, OUTREACH, AND RELATIONSHIP DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES TO BE CONDUCTED IN PHASE 1 OF THE PROGRAM. PHASE 2 WILL SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION, INCLUDING FOOD PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTION DIRECTLY BY COMMUNITY FOODBANK OF NEW JERSEY AND IN COLLABORATION WITH THE COMMON MARKET AS WELL AS THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE RESOURCES REQUIRED FOR LONG-TERM SUSTAINABILITY AND SUCCESS. IN ADDITION TO QUANTITATIVE METRICS IN SOURCING AND DISTRIBUTION, SUCCESS WILL BE JUDGED BY IMPROVED FARM TO FOOD PANTRY RELATIONSHIPS, GREATER ACCEPTANCE OF FARM FRESH PRODUCT AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL AND GREATER VARIETY IN THE PRODUCE DISTRIBUTED THROUGH THE CHARITABLE FOOD NETWORK, MATCHING PRODUCTION WITH DEMAND AT THE COMMUNITY LEVEL. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. JERSEY FRESH FOR ALL PROGRAM WILL BENEFIT LOCAL PRODUCERS THROUGHOUT THE STATE, TARGETING THOSE WHO ARE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED. THIS WILL INCLUDE BOTH RURAL FARMERS LOCATED IN THE COUNTIES WHERE NEW JERSEY’S FARMLAND IS MOST HIGHLY CONCENTRATED AS WELL AS SMALLER-SCALE URBAN AND PERI-URBAN FARMS. RECIPIENTS WILL BE THE NETWORK OF LOCAL DISTRIBUTION AGENCIES OF ALL EMERGENCY FEEDING ORGANIZATIONS OF THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, ULTIMATELY BENEFITING THE INDIVIDUALS AND HOUSEHOLDS THEY SERVE DIRECTLY. INFORMED BY THE COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND DATA COLLECTED FROM THE STAKEHOLDERS WE EXPECT TO IDENTIFY A TARGET OF 5-20 SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED GROWERS AND BEGIN PURCHASING FROM THEM. NEW JERSEY ESTIMATES THE NUMBER OF PEOPLE TO BE SERVED WITH FOOD FUNDED BY THE GRANT AT 250,000 INDIVIDUALS. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO COMMUNITY FOODBANK OF NEW JERSEY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION’S LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROJECT IS TO CREATE AND EXPAND COMMUNITY PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN EXISTING AGENCIES, ORGANIZATIONS, AND THEIR LOCAL AND REGIONAL DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS. PLANNED ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PARTNERSHIPS CONNECTING FARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND THEIR PRODUCTS TO HEALTHCARE ORGANIZATIONS, TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS, REGIONAL FOOD COLLECTIVES, MOBILE PANTRY PROGRAMS, FRESH PRODUCE BOX PROGRAMS, FOOD HUBS, AND ALLOWED PROCESSING FACILITIES. THE SUBRECIPIENT AGENCIES HAVE PLANS TO PURCHASE FOOD FROM LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS IN THEIR GEOGRAPHICAL AREA AND HAVE DEVELOPED DISTRIBUTION EFFORTS TO SUPPORT THEIR LOCAL UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. TARGETED FARMERS/PRODUCERS WILL INCLUDE “SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED GROUPS” WHOSE MEMBERS HAVE BEEN SUBJECT TO DISCRIMINATION ON THE BASIS OF RACE, COLOR, NATIONAL ORIGIN, AGE, DISABILITY, AND, WHERE APPLICABLE, SEX, MARITAL STATUS, FAMILIALSTATUS, PARENTAL STATUS, RELIGION, SEXUAL ORIENTATION, GENETIC INFORMATION, POLITICAL BELIEFS, REPRISAL, OR BECAUSE ALL OR A PART OF AN INDIVIDUAL'S INCOME IS DERIVED FROM ANY PUBLIC ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. THE EIGHT SUBAGENCIES COVER 50 COUNTIES IN THREE DISTINCT REGIONS OF MICHIGAN THAT REPRESENT CLIENTS FROM A POPULATION OF 5 MILLION MICHIGAN AREA RESIDENTS, REGIONS THAT ACCOUNT FOR OVER 50% OF MICHIGAN TEFAP HOUSEHOLDS AND INCLUDE EIGHT MICHIGAN TRIBAL ORGANIZATIONS. MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION’S EXPECTS SUBAGENCIES TO PARTNER WITH OVER 170 FARMERS/PRODUCERS AND DELIVER FOOD TO OVER 1,000 ,000 RECIPIENTS ACROSS SEVEN REGIONS IN MICHIGAN OVER THE TWO YEARS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION’S HAS INCLUDED MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY’S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES AS AN LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROJECT PARTNER TO CONDUCT DIRECT EVALUATION ACTIVITIES SUCH AS A SURVEYS, INTERVIEWS, AND/OR FOCUS GROUPS WITH FARMERS AND PRODUCERS ENGAGED IN THE PROJECT THROUGH CURRENT AND POTENTIAL SUB AWARD PARTNERS, ANALYSIS, AND BY SHARING RESULTS THROUGH A WRITTEN REPORTS. THE FOOD BANK COUNCIL OF MICHIGAN - SUPPORT SOCIALLY D ISADVANTAGED FARMERS/PRODUCERS AND UNDERSERVED AREAS IN NORTHERN MICHIGAN. KALAMAZOO VALLEY COMMUNITY COLLEGE SUPPORT SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND UNDERSERVED AREAS IN SOUTHWEST MICHIGAN. MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY’S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES CONDUCT EVALUATION ACTIVITIES WITH FARMERS AND PRODUCERS ENGAGED IN THE PROJECT THROUGH CURRENT AND POTENTIAL SUB AWARD PARTNERS. EASTERN MARKET: THE EASTERN MARKET WILL PARTNER WITH OAKLAND AVENUE URBAN FARMTO SUPPORT LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS TO PROVIDE 90,000 FRESH PRODUCE BOXES IN DETROIT AND THE DETROIT METRO AREA OVER THE FIRST TWO YEARS, COVERING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN THREE COUNTIES. FLINT FRESH: FLINT FRESH WILL PROVIDE 31 ,200 WEEKLY “VEGGIE BOXES” TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES IN FLINT AND SURROUNDING GENESEE COUNTY OVER THE INITIAL TWO YEARS. MID-MICHIGAN COMMUNITY ACTION: MID-MICHIGAN COMMUNITY ACTION HAS PROPOSED A COMMUNITY- SUPPORTED AGRICULTURE FOOD SHARE PROGRAM TO ESTABLISH PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN TARGETED LOCAL FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND LOCAL FOOD PANTRIES. THE THUMB FOOD POLICY COUNCIL WILL PROVIDE FRESH PRODUCE THROUGH A MOBILE DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM IN MICHIGAN’S NORTHEAST COUNTIES. WEST MICHIGAN FOOD PROCESSING ASSOCIATION: THIS PROJECT WILL DIRECTLY CONNECT GRANT-TARGETED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS WITH LOCAL FOOD AGENCIES, INCLUDING MEALS ON WHEELS, OTHER SENIOR MEAL PROGRAMS, PROGRAMS FOR UNDERSERVED CHILDREN, AND OTHER COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS PROVIDING MEALS OR FOOD FOR HOME USE. IN FISCAL YEAR 2023, AGREEMENT WAS AMENDED WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PLUS FUNDING TO INCREASE THE BUDGET WITH FUNDS AUTHORIZED BY THE COMMODITY CREDIT CORPORATION, AND TO INCREASE THE DURATION OF THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE. AS A RESULT OF THE ADDITIONAL FUNDING AND EXTENDED PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE, THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO PARTNER WITH SEVERAL SUBAWARDS TO EXPEND $11,457,815 TOWARD THE PURCHASE OF LOCALLY PRODUCED FOODS.

THE SINGLE SPRINGS BAND OF MIWOK INDIANS IS SEEKING LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE FUNDING TO BE UTILIZED FOR OUR UPCOMING PROJECT, HARVEST-TO-TABLE. THE HARVEST-TO-TABLE PROJECT WILL CONSIST OF PROVIDING LOCALLY GROWN FARM FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES, AND OTHER ALLOWABLE FOODS TO VULNERABLE AND AT-RISK INDIVIDUALS IN EL DORADO COUNTY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE SHINGLE SPRINGS BAND OF MIWOK INDIANS WILL PARTNER WITH THE FOOD BANK OF EL DORADO COUNTY, UTILIZING THEIR EMERGENCY FOOD NETWORK TO FACILITATE THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE FARM FRESH PRODUCE TO LOCAL COMMUNITIES OF VULNERABLE AND AT-RISK INDIVIDUALS ON A REGULAR BASIS FOR THE LENGTH OF THE PROGRAM. WE SEEK TO PARTNER WITH LOCAL GROWERS WHO ARE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED AND WILLING TO PARTNER LONG-TERM TO BECOME PART OF THE LOCAL FOOD ASSISTANCE NETWORK, SERVING UNDERSERVED INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE TOTAL ANTICIPATED NUMBER OF PRODUCERS THAT WILL BENEFIT FROM PARTNERING WITH THE HARVEST-TO-TABLE PROGRAM WILL RANGE FROM 12-15 LOCAL GROWERS. THE TOTAL ANTICIPATED NUMBER OF RECIPIENTS THAT ARE EXPECTED TO BENEFIT FROM THIS PROGRAM ARE 1500 - 2000 VULNERABLE, AT-RISK INDIVIDUALS INCLUDING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AND TRIBAL ENTITIES. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL TAKE A DUAL APPROACH TO THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASING ASSISTANCE PROJECT. THE TOTAL FUNDING AWARD WILL BE SPLIT INTO TWO SEPARATE “TRACKS:” 1) THE INDIANA WOMEN, INFANTS, AND CHILDREN PROGRAM, IN COLLABORATION WITH INDIANA STATE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, OVERSEE A STATEWIDE ACQUISITION AND DISTRIBUTION PROJECT THAT WILL PROVIDE GRANT FUNDING TO THE FRESH CONNECT COOPERATIVE CONSISTING OF ALL FOOD BANKS SERVING INDIANA TO IDENTIFY, ENGAGE AND PURCHASE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS, AND DISTRIBUTE THE FOOD TO IDENTIFIED UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; 2) THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH DIVISION OF NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY WILL OVERSEE A REGIONAL APPROACH THAT WILL DIVIDE THE STATE OF INDIANA INTO FIVE (5) DISTINCT REGIONS. PURCHASES WILL TARGET SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS AND WILL DELIVER PURCHASED PRODUCTS TO MARGINALIZED AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. PRODUCERS BENEFIT FROM NEW SALES AND THE ABILITY TO GROW THEIR BUSINESSES THUS ALLOWING FURTHER INCREASES IN SALES AND LONG-TERM RELATIONSHIPS WITH BUYERS. RECIPIENTS BENEFIT FROM RECEIVING HIGH-VALUE, LOCALLY PRODUCED FOOD PRODUCTS IN THEIR COMMUNITIES. WHERE APPLICABLE, GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL MAKE USE OF NEW LINES OF DISTRIBUTION CREATED THROUGH INFRASTRUCTURE ENHANCEMENTS ENABLED BY THE TEFAP REACH AND RESILIENCY GRANT. REGIONAL PARTNERSHIP COHORTS WILL IDENTIFY NEW DISTRIBUTION POINTS WITHIN UNDERSERVED INDIANA COMMUNITIES TO DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE-PURCHASED FOOD; UTILIZE LOCAL/REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS TO SUPPORT AND SUSTAIN THESE DISTRIBUTION POINTS LONG-TERM. TRACK 1 WILL ENGAGE A MINIMUM OF TWENTY (20) SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS, PRIORITIZING THOSE IN COUNTIES WITH HIGH MINORITY PERCENTAGES AND THOSE OFFERING PROTEIN PRODUCTS, AND CONDUCT A MINIMUM OF 10,000 RECIPIENT CONTACTS DURING THE GRANT PERIOD. TRACK 2 WILL WORK WITH THE FIVE (5) AWARDED REGIONAL PARTNERSHIP COHORTS TO IDENTIFY ELIGIBLE PRODUCERS AND RECIPIENTS. THE APPROACHES AND EXPECTED PROJECT BENEFICIARIES WILL LIKELY DIFFER AMONG THE PARTNERSHIP GROUPS, BUT THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH DIVISION OF NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY HAS DEFINED BASELINE EXPECTATIONS WITHIN THE REQUEST FOR PROPOSALS. ALL FOOD PURCHASED THROUGH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE TRACK 2 FUNDING MUST COME FROM LOCAL, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE REGIONAL PARTNERSHIP COHORTS WILL MAINTAIN CONNECTION TO AND ALIGNMENT WITH THE EXISTING STATEWIDE VALUE CHAIN NETWORK TO PROVIDE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND ECONOMIC EXPANSION STRATEGIES FOR PARTICIPATING, REGIONAL PRODUCERS. THEDEPARTMENT OF HEALTH DIVISION OF NUTRITION AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY WILL OVERSEE THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW REGIONAL PARTNERSHIPS, COMMUNICATION, AND FOOD PATHWAYS THAT LEAD TO MORE ROBUST, THRIVING, AND RESILIENT REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS.

THE COWLITZ INDIAN TRIBE HAS BEGUN A COLLABORATIVE PILOT PROGRAM TO SOLVE HUNGER IN OUR LOCAL NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITIES. THE TRIBE AND LOCAL FOOD AGENCIES ARE WORKING TOGETHER ON A TWO-YEAR PROJECT TO IMPROVE NUTRITION SECURITY AND INCREASE FOOD SOVEREIGNTY FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS. OUR TRIBE, WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDING,  INTENDS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. OUR PROGRAM WILL BUILD PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL, DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS IN WESTERN WASHINGTON TO SUPPLEMENT OUR FRESH FOOD NEEDS. WE HAVE IDENTIFIED AND WILL CONTRACT WITH SEVERAL LOCAL PRODUCERS FOR FRUITS, VEGETABLES, MEATS, DAIRY, AND DRY GOODS SUCH AS RICE, GRAINS, AND BREAD. WE ALSO SEEK A LOCAL PRODUCER TO SUPPLY TRADITIONAL MEATS SUCH AS ELK, DEER, AND BEAR. THIS DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM WILL DEDICATE ITSELF TO BRINGING FRESH PRODUCE AND INDIGENOUS FOOD TO OUR COMMUNITY FOR HEALTHY DIETS. WE ARE BUILDING A SOLID NETWORK OF SUPPORT FOR THE FOOD SYSTEMS THAT KEEP OUR COMMUNITY HEALTHY AND THRIVING. PARTNERING WITH LOCAL FOOD PRODUCERS WILL ENSURE THAT THE REVENUE WILL REMAIN IN OUR LOCAL ECONOMY AND ACCELERATE THE FOOD PRODUCER'S GROWTH AND SUSTAINABILITY. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRO DUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. OUR DISTRIBUTION PROGRAM WILL DELIVER FRESH AND NUTRITIOUS MEALS TO OVER 880 HISTORICALLY DISADVANTAGED AMERICAN INDIAN FAMILIES LIVING IN WESTERN WASHINGTON STATE. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT THE CHICKAHOMINY INDIAN TRIBE EASTERN DIVISION WILL “WATCH OUR ROOTS GROW” ITS AIMED AT BETTERING OUR LOCAL FARM COMMUNITY AND THE UNDERSERVED NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITY. BY PURCHASING LOCAL MEATS AND PRODUCE FROM FARMS IN OUR AREA WE WILL BE BETTERING OUR LOCAL AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY AND ALSO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THE BENEFITS OF PURCHASING LOCAL, INCLUDING SAVING MONEY. WE WILL AID OUR COMMUNITY WITH FOOD NEEDS TO HELP DEFRAY THE RISING COST OF FOOD. WE CURRENTLY HOST TRIBAL PANTRY DAYS WHERE WE HAND OUT CARE PACKAGES TO OUR TRIBAL MEMBERS WHICH INCLUDE A VARIETY OF PERISHABLE AND NON-PERISHABLE GOODS. WE WILL PURCHASE UP TO FIVE WHOLE PROCESSED COWS, 20 PROCESSED CHICKENS, FOUR PROCESSED PIGS AND MISCELLANEOUS DAIRY PRODUCTS FOR UP TO 80 TRIBAL MEMBERS EACH PANTRY DAY. CHICKAHOMINY'S LITTLE ARROWS IS OUR CHILDCARE PROGRAM, WE CURRENTLY HAVE 22 CHILDREN IN ATTENDANCE AT OUR CHILDCARE FACILITY WITH A MAXIMUM CAPACITY OF 96 CHILDREN. OUR CHILDCARE PANTRY IS RESTOCKED EVERY 1-2 WEEKS THESE FOODS INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, YOGURT, CRACKERS, CHEESE, WHOLE GRAINS, CHIPS, APPLESAUCE, AND CONDIMENTS. WE INTEND TO INVOLVE AS MANY LOCAL FARMS AND PRODUCERS AS POSSIBLE. OUR HOPE IS THAT AS WE BEGIN THIS PROJECT WE MAY LEARN ABOUT EVEN MORE LOCAL FARMS AND/OR BUSINESSES IN WHICH WE CAN PARTNER WITH. HOLLY FORK FARMS IS A FAMILY FARM LOCATED IN EASTERN NEW KENT COUNTY. BURKS FARM HAS BEEN PROCESSING MEATS IN NEW KENT COUNTY SINCE 2001. OAK GROVE FARM <(>&<)> MEATS LLC HAS BEEN IN BUSINESS SINCE 2015 RAISING AND SELLING MEATS. THEY ALSO OFFER VEGETABLES, CANNED GOODS, AND BAKED GOODS. GALLMEYER FARMS RUNS A VEGGIE STAND IN RICHMOND VA AND OFFERS A VERY WIDE VARIETY OF LOCALLY GROWN PRODUCE AND SELL LOCAL HONEY. THEY GROW VEGETABLES AND ALSO BUY LOCALLY GROWN PRODUCE FROM LOCAL FARM FAMILIES IN THE SURROUNDING AREAS. BOROUGH’S LAND FARM BEGAN IN 2008 AND THEIR MISSION IS TO PROVIDE THE FRESHEST, HIGHEST QUALITY VIRGINIA GROWN PRODUCTS. BORROUGH’S IS COMPRISED OF A GROUP OF HARD-WORKING FARM FAMILIES DEDICATED TO GROWING AND PRODUCING HEALTHY FOOD. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. WE ANTICIPATE THAT 90% OF OUR NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES WILL BE ESTABLISHED THROUGH THIS PROGRAM, WITH 75% OF THEM BEING SUSTAINED AFTER THE PROGRAM IS OVER. WE ANTICIPAT E THAT 100% OF THE FOOD DISTRIBUTED WILL SERVE OUR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY AND THAT AT LEAST 50% OF THE FOOD DISTRIBUTION WILL CONTINUE AFTER THE PROGRAM HAS CONCLUDED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.  THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES ARE BRINGING TOGETHER STAKEHOLDERS TO CREATE A MEANINGFUL AND SUSTAINABLE MODEL TO BRIDGE LOCALLY GROWN AND RAISED PRODUCTS OF UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND RANCHERS TO FOOD INSECURE COMMUNITIES. THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT IS AN OPPORTUNITY TO UNITE ILLINOISANS INVESTED IN BUILDING A RESILIENT FOOD SYSTEM AND BUILD A COLLABORATIVE NETWORK OF FOOD SYSTEM SUPPORT. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROGRAM PRIORITIZES ENSURING CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE FRESH FOODS ARE AVAILABLE TO FOOD INSECURE COMMUNITIES. YEAR ONE OF THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN. ILLINOIS IS LARGE AND DIVERSE STATE, WITH AGRICULTURE AS IT’S NUMBER ONE INDUSTRY. THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE NOTES THAT A NETWORK OF AGGREGATION AND DISTRIBUTION HUBS IS NEEDED TO IMPLEMENT THIS PROGRAM. THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE WILL ENTER INTO AN INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT WITH UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS COOPERATIVE EXTENSION TO SERVE AS NEUTRAL FACILITATORS OF THE “GROWING ILLINOIS” ADVISORY BOARD. THE ADVISORY BOARD WILL BE COMPRISED OF A DIVERSE GROUP OF STAKEHOLDERS KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT CURRENT FARM AND FOOD SYSTEMS ACROSS THE STATE AND THOSE COMMITTED TO ENSURING EQUITABLE ACCESS TO CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE FOODS. YEAR TWO WILL BEGIN WITH A NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY FOR THE ISSUANCE OF SUBAWARDS FOR MANAGEMENT OF MULTIPLE STATE-WIDE AGGREGATE SITES. THESE SITES WILL SERVE AS COLLECTION SITES FOR PRODUCTS FROM UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE DEPARTMENTS ARE COMMITTED TO PURCHASING 100% OF PRODUCTS FROM UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND RANCHERS AND DISTRIBUTING TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. AN ADVISORY BOARD IS CRITICAL TO THE LONG-TERM SUCCESS OF LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS AS THE STATE OF ILLINOIS DOES NOT CURRENTLY HAVE A DEFINED STRUCTURE IN PLACE THAT PROVIDES AGGREGATION SITES FOR UNDERSERVED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE STATE LOOKS TO UTILIZE THIS COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT TO ESTABLISH SUSTAINABLE SYSTEMS AND NETWORKS THAT CURRENTLY DO NOT EXIST. IN AN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN PREPARED BY UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS EXTENSION. THE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WILL INCLUDE THE DETAILS FOR RELEASING A NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY TO SELECT RECIPIENTS OF SUBAWARDS. SUBAWARD RECIPIENTS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR ESTABLISHING AGGREGATION AND DISTRIBUTION SITES WITHIN PRE-DETERMINED REGIONS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE RESULTS OF THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WILL BE POSTED TO THE ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE’S WEBSITE, DISTRIBUTED TO AGRICULTURAL ORGANIZATIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS THAT PROVIDE FOOD AND RESOURCES TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THIS INCLUDES PARTICIPATING TEFAP ORGANIZATIONS. UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS EXTENSION ADVISORY BOARD, AND ILLINOIS DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SERVICES WILL ISSUE A NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY TO PROVIDE SUBAWARDS TO FOOD DISTRIBUTION SYSTEMS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. IN FISCAL YEAR 2023, AGREEMENT WAS AMENDED WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PLUS FUNDING TO INCREASE THE BUDGET WITH FUNDS AUTHORIZED BY THE COMMODITY CREDIT CORPORATION, AND TO INCREASE THE DURATION OF THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE. AS A RESULT OF THE ADDITIONAL FUNDING AND EXTENDED PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE, THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO PURCHASE AN ESTIMATED $23,000,000.00 IN FOOD PROCUREMENT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.  WITH FUNDING FROM THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM, THE TUNICA BILOXI TRIBE OF LOUISIANA WILL ESTABLISH A PROGRAM TO EMPOWER OUR TRIBAL COMMUNITY TO DETERMINE HOW LOCAL FOOD CAN BE PROCURED AND DISTRIBUTED TO UNDERSERVED TRIBAL CITIZENS. THE TRIBE WILL ISSUE REQUEST FOR PROPOSAL FROM LOCAL FARMERS TO BEGIN PURCHASING FOOD FOR TRIBAL FAMILIES IN NEED. THE TRIBAL COUNCIL WILL WORK WITH THE TRIBE’S PROCUREMENT OFFICE TO EXPEDITE CONTRACTS WITH LOCAL SUPPLIERS. LOCAL AND TRIBAL FOOD PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTION WILL BE COMMUNITY DRIVEN WITH THE TRIBAL GOVERNMENT GETTING BUY-IN FROM TRIBAL GOVERNMENT UNITS SUCH AS SOCIAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT, EDUCATION DEPARTMENT, HEALTH DEPARTMENT, HOUSING DEPARTMENT, THE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM, AND COLLABORATION WITH STATE AND LOCAL AGENCIES TO IDENTIFY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS/FOOD PRODUCERS AND TRIBAL FAMILIES FACING FOOD INSECURITY. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE TRIBE WILL INVEST AT LEAST $250,000 THOUSAND DOLLARS INTO FOOD PURCHASED FROM LOCAL FARMERS OVER THE COURSE OF TWO YEARS WITH A MINIMUM OF 51 PERCENT OF THOSE DOLLARS BEING SPENT ON PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS. THE TRIBE ALSO HOPES TO PRIORITIZE AND STREAMLINE PROCUREMENT OF FOOD THAT CAN BE DISTRIBUTED WITHIN THE COMMUNITY WHILE PROVIDING TRIBAL MEMBERS THE OPPORTUNITY TO DETERMINE PATHWAYS AND PARAMETERS FOR PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTION THAT CAN MEET THE UNIQUE NEEDS OF FARMERS AND UNDERSERVED MEMBERS OF THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY. CONTRACTS PROVIDED TO TRIBAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS WILL BE EVALUATED TO DEMONSTRATE PRODUCT RELIABILITY, DELIVERY AND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND IMPROVE THEIR LONG-TERM CHANCES ACCESSING NEW MARKETS. ADDITIONAL PROGRAM EVALUATION FRAMEWORK WILL BE DEVELOPED THAT IS EASY TO USE TO MEET REPORTING REQUIREMENTS AND ASSESS ADDITIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE NEEDS FOR DEVELOPING FUTURE FOOD SYSTEMS IN THE STATE. PUBLIC FEEDBACK WILL BE EVALUATED TO CONTINUE EFFECTIVE OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT TO ASSIST WITH THE DESIGN OF PROGRAMS AND POLICIES. WE INTEND TO WORK WITH APPROXIMATELY 20 LOCAL FARMS THAT PRODUCE DIVERSIFIED FRUIT AND VEGETABLE, LIVESTOCK AND DAIRY, AND GATHERERS OF TRADITIONAL FOODS SUCH AS CRAWFISH. FOOD DISTRIBUTION BENEFICIARIES WILL INCLUDE TRIBAL MEMBERS ON THE OFFICIAL ENROLMENT REGISTRY WHO ARE IN NEED OR CONSIDERED FOOD INSECURE. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE WYANDOTTE NATION LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM WILL MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. WYANDOTTE NATION PLANS TO ESTABLISH NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES BY PURCHASING FRUIT, VEGETABLES, DAIRY, AND PROTEIN FROM LOCAL PRODUCERS AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS IN ORDER TO DISTRIBUTE FOOD FRESH AND NUTRITIOUS FOODS TO OUR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY. MEASUREMENT OF SUCCESS WILL BE DETERMINED BY THE COMPLETION OF THE PROGRAM AND ITS INTENDED RESULTS. SUCCESS OF THE PROJECT WILL BE SHARED WITH THE COMMUNITY THROUGH THE TRIBE’S MONTHLY NEWSPAPER, FACEBOOK PAGE, AND TRIBAL WEBSITE. WYANDOTTE NATION WILL BE SHARING LESSONS LEARNED OF PROMISING BEST PRACTICES WITH OTHER AMERICAN INDIAN AND FIRST NATION COMMUNITIES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. OUR PROJECT WILL BENEFIT AT LEAST FOUR LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND APPROXIMATELY 175 UNDERSERVED FAMILIES IN OUR TRIBAL COMMUNITY INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, NATIVE AMERICAN PERSONS, PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES, PERSONS WHO LIVE IN RURAL AREAS, AND PERSONS OTHERWISE ADVERSELY AFFECTED BY PERSISTENT POVERTY OR INEQUALITY. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOODTARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.THE UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, AGRICULTURAL MARKETINGSERVICE HAS ESTABLISHED THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVEAGREEMENT PROGRAM. THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVEAGREEMENT PROGRAM IS PART OF THE “BUILD BACK BETTER” INITIATIVE,AUTHORIZED BY THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN. LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCECOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM PURPOSE IS TO MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE FOODAND AGRICULTURAL SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY TO SUPPORT LOCAL, REGIONAL, ANDSOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS THROUGH THE PURCHASE OFLOCALLY GROWN FRESH FOODS, FOOD PRODUCTS, AND BEVERAGES. THE TENNESSEEDEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE IS PARTNERING WITH THE FIVE REGIONAL FOODBANKS.  THE FOOD BANKS WILL SERVE AS SUBRECIPIENTS OF THE LOCAL FOODPURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM GRANT PROGRAM.  THEFOOD BANKS WILL WORK TO IDENTIFY NEW PARTNERSHIPS FOR LOCAL AND REGIONALFARMERS/PRODUCERS ACROSS TENNESSEE. EACH OF THE FIVE REGIONAL FOOD BANKSWILL CONDUCT AN INTERNAL REVIEW TO DETERMINE THE FOLLOWING NEEDS: OUTREACH EFFORTS ACROSS THE STATE, PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT, AND PROGRAM ADMINISTRATION. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTEDTO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS ANDRANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDSEXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OFNEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENTFOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE PRIMARY GOAL REGARDING FOOD IN THISPROGRAM IS TO KEEP THE FOOD DISTRIBUTION WITHIN THE FOOD BANKS SERVICEAREA AND TO SHARE ANY EXCESS ACROSS THE STATE. THE TENNESSEE DEPARTMENTOF AGRICULTURE ANTICIPATES THE REGIONAL FOOD BANKS, AS SUBAWARDRECIPIENTS, WILL IDENTIFY AT LEAST SEVENTY DISADVANTAGEDFARMERS/PRODUCERS AND OVER ONE MILLION BENEFICIARIES OF THE LOCAL FOODPURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM. THE RECIPIENT PLANSTO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO SECOND HARVEST OF MIDDLE TENNESSEE, SECOND HARVESTOF EAST TENNESSEE, SECOND HARVEST OF NORTHEAST TENNESSEE, CHATTANOOGAAREA FOOD BANK AND MID-SOUTH FOOD BANK.

THE NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES IS SUB-AWARDING $1,600,000 TO THE NEBRASKA CHILDREN AND FAMILIES FOUNDATION TO CREATE A COLLABORATIVE NETWORK TO FOCUS ON PROCURING FOOD FROM LOCAL,SMALL, AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND DISTRIBUTINGTHOSE FARM PRODUCTS TO NEBRASKANS WHO ARE UNDERSERVED BY TRADITIONALFOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMANSERVICES INTENDS TO DEVELOP REGIONAL COMMUNITIES OF PRACTICE BY BRINGINGTOGETHER PRODUCERS, DISTRIBUTORS, FOOD HUBS, FOOD BANKS, ADVOCATES,THOSE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED FOOD INSECURITY, AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS FORTHE PURPOSE OF ALIGNING LOCAL FOOD PRODUCTION WITH NEEDS AND TO IMPROVETHE EFFECTIVENESS AND EQUITY OF FOOD PROCUREMENT, PURCHASING, ANDDISTRIBUTION FOR NEBRASKA’S FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. QUARTERLYPERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OFPRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTIONSITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDSEXPENDED FOR EACHCATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETINGOPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTIONNETWORKS. THROUGH THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM, THENEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES WILL MITIGATE FOODINSECURITY AND CREATE STABILITY FOR PRODUCERS BY ESTABLISHING A FOODSUPPLY CHAIN USING LOCAL VEGETABLES, FRUITS, PROTEINS, AND DAIRY USINGCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT FUNDS FROM THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCEPROGRAM. THIS WORK WILL BE DONE IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NEBRASKA CHILDREN AND FAMILIES FOUNDATION VIA A SUBAWARD AGREEMENT. ON THE PRODUCER SIDE OF THE SUPPLY CHAIN, DURING THE PANDEMIC, MANYORGANIZATIONS STEPPED FORWARD TO WORK WITH PRODUCERS TO HELP THEM FINDNEW MARKETS FOR THEIR GOODS AND IMPROVE THE OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY OF THEIR BUSINESS. WORKING COLLABORATIVELY WITH EXPERTS ACROSS THE FOOD SUPPLY CHAIN, NEBRASKA CHILDREN AND FAMILIES FOUNDATION WILLFORM THE NEBRASKA LOCAL HEALTHY FOOD COMMITTEE TO ENGAGE AND RECRUITFARMERS, RANCHERS, AND THOSE WHO DISTRIBUTE FOOD TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES INTO THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM. BASED ON THE MOST RECENT CENSUS OF AGRICULTURE FOR NEBRASKA, THERE AREAPPROXIMATELY 7,670 PRODUCERS THAT FIT THE DEFINITION OF SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED. ANOTHER 6,965 PRODUCERS HAVE MILITARY SERVICE, AND ROUGHLY 16,740 ARE NEW AND BEGINNING FARMERS FROM WHICH THE NEBRASKA LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM INTENDS TO PROCURE FOOD.THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO NEBRASKA CHILDREN AND FAMILIESFOUNDATION.
