THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOODTARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, TRADE AND CONSUMER PROTECTIONWILL PARTNER WITH THE MIDWEST ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLE EDUCATION SERVICE,THE WISCONSIN FARMERS UNION AND THE WISCONSIN FOOD HUB COOPERATIVE TOENGAGE AND CONVENE PRODUCERS, DISTRIBUTORS, COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS,FOOD SECURITY PARTNERS AND TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS TO ESTABLISH LOCAL FOODSYSTEM CONNECTIONS AND A PIPELINE IN WHICH SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDPRODUCERS CAN SECURE MARKETS AND PROVIDE LOCAL FOOD TO UNDERSERVEDCOMMUNITIES. WISCONSIN FARMERS UNION WILL HIRE REGIONAL AND COMMUNITYSPECIFIC LOCAL FOOD ORGANIZERS TO NETWORK FOOD SYSTEM AND FOOD SECURITYPARTNERS IN EACH REGION TO ENSURE EQUITABLE ACCESS ACROSS THE STATE. INTHE SECOND PHASE JAN THROUGH APR 2023 MIDWEST ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLEEDUCATION SERVICE WILL AWARD CONTRACTS FOR PROCUREMENT TO PRODUCERS ANDPROVIDE PROGRAMMING FOCUSED ON PRODUCTION PLANNING THROUGH DIRECT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING TO GROWERS SUPPLYING THE PROGRAM.  IN THE THIRD PHASE MAY THROUGH DEC 2023 WISCONSIN FOOD HUBCOOPERATIVE WILL COORDINATE PROCUREMENT AND MANAGE LOGISTICS ANDDISTRIBUTION. THIS PROJECT AIMS TO PURCHASE PRODUCT FROM APPROXIMATELY150 PRODUCERS WITH A TARGET GOAL OF AT LEAST 80%, 120 OF THE TOTAL 150PRODUCERS PURCHASED FROM PRODUCERS THAT QUALIFY AS UNDERSERVED OR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS. VETERAN, HMONG, TRIBAL, WOMEN, BLACK, IMMIGRANT FARMERS AND OTHER UNDER-REPRESENTED ANDUNDER-RESOURCED PRODUCERS, AS WELL AS THE SUPPLY CHAIN PARTNERS ANDORGANIZATIONS THAT SUPPORT THEM, WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENGAGE,NETWORK, COLLABORATE THROUGH THE WISCONSIN LOCAL FOOD PURCHASEASSISTANCE PROGRAM. THE GOAL IS TO BRING MULTIPLE NETWORKS TOGETHER ANDSUPPORT SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS IN SECURING CONTRACTS, CONNECTINGTO SUPPORTS AND ACCESSING SYSTEMS TO SUPPLY FOR THE PROGRAM. QUARTERLYPERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OFPRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTIONSITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACHCATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETINGOPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTIONNETWORKS. THE FOURTH PHASE IS FOR CAPTURING LESSONS LEARNED ANDSTORYTELLING. OUR GOAL IS TO CREATE CONNECTIVITY FOR WISCONSIN’S LOCALFOOD SYSTEM, LASTING MARKET OPPORTUNITIES FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDPRODUCERS, INCLUSIVE AND EQUITABLE FOOD ACCESS FOR ALL COMMUNITIESTHROUGH INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS, AND INCREASED COORDINATION AND NETWORKING.MIDWEST ORGANIC AND SUSTAINABLE EDUCATION SERVICE WILL OVERSEEPROCUREMENT AND FARMER TRAINING. WISCONSIN FARMER’S UNION WILL OVERSEESTAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT AND ASSET MAPPING. WISCONSIN FOOD HUB COOPERATIVEWILL OVERSEE ALL DISTRIBUTION OF PRODUCT TO DISTRIBUTION SITES ANDASSIST WITH PRODUCER ENGAGEMENT.

THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE INTENDS TO USE LOCAL FOODPURCHASE AGREEMENT FUNDS TO ESTABLISH A PROGRAM THAT ALLOWS COMMUNITIESTO DETERMINE FOR THEMSELVES HOW LOCAL FOOD CAN BE PROCURED ANDDISTRIBUTED TO UNDERSERVED INDIVIDUALS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT ISTO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.  THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OFAGRICULTURE WILL ISSUE A CALL FOR COMMUNITY PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTIONPROJECT PROPOSALS IN FALL 2022. THESE PROPOSALS ARE EXPECTED TOENCOMPASS A WIDE RANGE OF MODELS FOR LOCAL FOOD PROCUREMENT ANDDISTRIBUTION, KNOWING THAT THERE IS NO ONE-SIZE-FITS-ALL MODEL THAT CANEFFECTIVELY SERVE THE WHOLE STATE. PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTION WILLTAKE PLACE DURING 2023 AND 2024. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BESUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDFARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS ASWELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDEPERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTEDBEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. A MINIMUM OF LEAST $1,950,000OF LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM FUNDING WILL BE INVESTED INTOFOOD PURCHASED FROM LOCAL FARMERS OVER THE COURSE OF TWO YEARS.  AN ESTIMATED SEVENTY PERCENT OF THOSE DOLLARS WILL BE SPENT ON PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS. PROCUREMENT OF FOOD THAT CANBE DISTRIBUTED WITHIN THE COMMUNITY THAT IT IS PRODUCED WILL BEPRIORITIZED. AN AWARDEE FRIENDLY EVALUATION AND GRANT REPORTING FRAMEWORK WILL BE DEVELOPED TO ASSESS ADDITIONAL NEEDS FOR LOCAL AND REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS. THE PROCESS OF PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT WILL ALSOBE EVALUATED TO PROVIDE THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE INSIGHTINTO REFINING CONTINUED EFFECTIVE OUTREACH AND ENGAGEMENT FOR PROGRAMSAND POLICIES. THE EXPECTATION FOR THIS PROGRAM IS TO WORK WITH AT LEAST30 ORGANIZATIONS TO PURCHASE FOOD FROM AN ESTIMATED 140 LOCAL FARMS ANDDISTRIBUTE THAT FOOD DIRECTLY TO MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITIES CLOSEST TOTHOSE FARMS. THESE PRODUCERS WILL INCLUDE DIVERSIFIED FRUIT ANDVEGETABLE GROWERS, LIVESTOCK, AND DAIRY FARMERS, THOSE WHO HAVEINTEGRATED SPECIALTY CROP-LIVESTOCK OPERATIONS, AND GATHERERS OFTRADITIONAL FOODS SUCH AS WILD RICE. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TOSUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THESE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANT FUNDS WILL BE UTILIZED TO (1) INCREASE PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING CAPACITY OF GEORGIA GROWN BEEF AND SPECIALTY FOODS, (2) DISTRIBUTE FOOD THROUGHOUT GEORGIA TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, (3) GENERATE REVENUE FOR SOCIAL DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. TO DO THIS, GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE WILL, THROUGH THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANT PROGRAM, (1) INCREASE PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING CAPACITY OF GEORGIA GROWN BEEF AND SPECIALTY FOODS, (2) DISTRIBUTE FOOD THROUGHOUT GEORGIA TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, AND (3) GENERATE REVENUE FOR SOCIAL DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. AS PART OF THIS PROGRAM, GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND ITS COLLABORATORS WILL PROVIDE OUTREACH, TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, AND COORDINATION WITH SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGE PRODUCERS ACROSS GEORGIA TO HELP INCREASE THE STATE’S FOOD PRODUCTION. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. OUR GOAL IS FOR 100% OF FOOD PURCHASED FOR THIS PROGRAM TO COME FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO INCREASE ACCESS TO LOCAL FOOD AND IMPROVE SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY BY BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL PRODUCERS OF VARYING SIZE, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS/PRODUCERS, AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. A DESIRED OUTCOME OF THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANT IS FOR APPROXIMATELY 50% OF ESTABLISHED PARTNERSHIPS TO CONTINUE AFTER THE PROGRAM CONCLUDES. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE RESIDENTS OF THE STATE OF GEORGIA. THERE ARE THREE DISCRETE BENEFICIARY GROUPS OF THE GEORGIA LO CAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANT PROGRAM THAT WILL INCLUDE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED RANCHERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED SPECIALTY FOODS PRODUCERS AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO PLANT STATED, SWANSON FAMILY FARM, FLINT RIVER FRESH, ATLANTA COMMUNITY FOOD BANK AND GEORGIA FOOD BANKS. IN FISCAL YEAR 2023, AGREEMENT WAS AMENDED WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PLUS FUNDING TO INCREASE THE BUDGET WITH FUNDS AUTHORIZED BY THE COMMODITY CREDIT CORPORATION, AND TO INCREASE THE DURATION OF THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE.

THE PURPOSE OF THE CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO FOOD EXCHANGE IS TO EXPAND THETRIBES’ FOOD PANTRY AND DISTRIBUTION CENTER SERVICES BY ADDING MOREDIRECT FOOD PURCHASING FROM LOCAL AND DISADVANTAGED FARMERS ANDPRODUCERS TO INCLUDE MEATS, FRESH FRUITS, AND VEGETABLES BY PICKING UPPRODUCE FROM FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AND DEVELOPING A PROGRAM FORUNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO USE WITH DESIGNATED FARMERS ANDPRODUCERS IN THEIR AREA BETWEEN DISTRIBUTION DATES WITH THE TRIBES.  THECHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO TRIBES WILL SUBMIT QUARTERLY REPORTS ACCOUNTING FORTHE RECEIPT AND DISBURSEMENT OF THE FUNDS. THE QUARTERLY FEDERALFINANCIAL REPORTS (SF-425) WILL BE COMPLETED BY THE CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHOFINANCE DIVISION. THIS REPORT WILL BE SUBMITTED NO LATER THAN 10 DAYSAFTER THE END OF EACH CALENDAR QUARTER AND WILL INCLUDE INFORMATIONREGARDING THE AMOUNT OF FUNDS DRAWN DOWN, THE AMOUNT OF FUNDS EXPENDEDFOR EACH ACTIVITY, AND A DETAILED LIST AND DESCRIPTION OF THE ITEM’SAPPLICATION TO EACH ACTIVITY. ANNUAL REPORTING WILL BE SUBMITTED INACCORDANCE WITH THE DEADLINES INDICATED IN THE NOTICE OF FUNDING. ANNUALSTATUS AND EVALUATION REPORTS WILL REPORT ON THE PROGRESS AND IMPACTMADE BY PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION AFTER THE GRANT IS FULLY EXPENDED.QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL ALSO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS,SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, ANDUNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTIONNETWORKS. THE CHEYENNE AND ARAPAHO TRIBES WILL REACH OUT TO SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED LOCAL FARMERS AND PRODUCERS TO CREATE A WORKING RELATIONSHIP TO PURCHASE THEIR PRODUCTS TO BE PICKED UP AND DELIVERED TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS WITHIN THE TRIBES ELEVEN HISTORICCOUNTY BOUNDARIES IN WESTERN OKLAHOMA. THESE WORKING RELATIONSHIPS WILLBE CONFIRMED WITH A CONTRACT STATING THE REQUIREMENTS AND EXPECTATIONSOF THE VENDORS, FARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND THE TRIBES. THE TRIBES WILL ALSOWORK WITH THESE FARMERS AND PRODUCERS TO CREATE A SYSTEM IN WHICHUNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS CAN USE TO ACQUIRE FOOD FROM FARMERS ANDPRODUCES DIRECTLY WITH THE INTENTION OF LOWERING FOOD INSECURITY DURINGTIME PERIODS BETWEEN FOOD PANTRY DISTRIBUTION DATES. THE TRIBES WILLCONTINUE TO WORK WITH EXISTING VENDORS WHILE ESTABLISHING WORKINGRELATIONSHIPS WITH NEW LOCAL FARMERS AND PRODUCERS AT FAMERS MARKETSLOCAL TO THE TRIBES’ HISTORIC BOUNDARIES TO PURCHASE MEAT, FRESH FRUITS,AND VEGETABLES FOR UNDERSERVED COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE INTENDEDRECIPIENTS BENEFITTING FROM THIS PROGRAM WILL INCLUDE ELDERLY WITHCHILDREN, DISABLED, UNEMPLOYED, SINGLE PARENTS (NOT RECEIVING SNAPBENEFITS), THOSE WITH DIETARY RESTRICTIONS, UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, ANDTRIBAL MEMBERS. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

AFTER THE NOTICE OF AWARD, THE CHIPPEWA CREE WILL ORIENT STAFF AS TOTHE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCECOOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM. THE TRIBE WILL THEN RESEARCH AND DEVELOPA LIST OF LOCAL SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS THAT COULDPOTENTIALLY PARTICIPATE IN THE SUPPLY OF DOMESTIC FOOD PRODUCTS. ASOLICITATION NOTICE FOR THE PROCUREMENT OF DOMESTIC FOOD PRODUCTS THATSTRICTLY ADHERES TO THE CHIPPEWA CREE TRIBE’S PROCUREMENT POLICIES ANDPROCEDURES WILL BE ADVERTISED IN LOCAL MEDIA OUTLETS TARGETING SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED FARMERS/PRODUCERS. ONCE ACCEPTABLE BIDS ARE RECEIVED,ORDERS FOR DOMESTIC FOOD PRODUCTS WILL BE PLACED AND SCHEDULED FORDELIVERY TO THE CHIPPEWA CREE HELP LODGE FOR DISTRIBUTION. THE SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND PRODUCERS WE INTEND TO TARGET OUR PURCHASESFROM RESIDE ON OR NEAR THE ROCKY BOY’S INDIAN RESERVATION IN BOX ELDER,MONTANA. THE RECIPIENTS OF THE PURCHASES WILL BE UNDERSERVED ANDIMPOVERISHED TRIBAL MEMBERS WHO ARE MOST IN NEED OF ASSISTANCE WITHACQUIRING HEALTHY AND NUTRITIOUS FOODS FOR THEIR FAMILIES. THE CREETRIBE WILL DEVELOP A PROMISING PRACTICES GUIDE DETAILING PROJECTSUCCESSES, CHALLENGES, AND OUTCOMES ACHIEVED THROUGH THE PROJECT ASMEASURED BY THE REPORT DEVELOPED, ON FILE, AND AVAILABLE FORREPLICATION. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURETHE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS,DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDEDFOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEWMARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOODDISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. THE TRIBE EXPECTS TO PROVIDE FOOD TO 768INDIVIDUALS OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT PERIOD. THE PROJECT ISEXPECTED TO RESULT IN THE ESTABLISHMENT OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIESFOR A MINIMUM OF FIVE VENDORS OF DOMESTIC FOODS FROM LOCAL FARMERS ANDPRODUCERS WITH AT LEAST 60 PERCENT BEING SUSTAINED AFTER FUNDING ISEXPENDED. IN ADDITION, WE EXPECT TO ENGAGE A MINIMUM OF THREE SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED VENDORS OF DOMESTIC FOODS FROM LOCAL FARMERS AND PRODUCERSWHO WILL PROVIDE DOMESTIC FOOD FOR DISTRIBUTION. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOTINTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOODTARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS,AND TO PROVIDE FOOD ASSISTANCE TO THE MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT TRIBALCOMMUNITY. THE MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT TRIBAL NATION IS A FEDERALLYRECOGNIZED TRIBAL NATION LOCATED IN SOUTHEASTERN CONNECTICUT.MASHANTUCKET PEQUOT TRIBAL NATION IS TAKING A TWO-PRONGED APPROACH TOPURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTION OF HEALTHY ORGANIC FOOD TO THE TRIBALCOMMUNITY. FOR ACTIVITY NUMBER 1, FUNDS WILL BE USED TO PURCHASETRIBALLY-GROWN FRUITS, VEGETABLES, MEAT, AND TRIBALLY-PRODUCED MAPLESYRUP FROM THE TRIBAL-OWNED MEECHOOOK FARM AND SUGAR SHACK. THE FARM ISRUN BY TRIBAL MEMBER EMPLOYEES (FARMERS). ON A BI-WEEKLY BASIS PRODUCEWILL BE BAGGED AND BOXED AND DISTRIBUTED (IN PERSON OR BY DELIVERY) TOTRIBAL HOUSEHOLDS ON AND OFF THE RESERVATION; BUT WITHIN THE CONFINES OFCONNECTICUT. WE WILL DO THIS BY USING FUNDS TO HIRE TWO FULL-TIMEDELIVERY STAFF, PURCHASE FOOD DISTRIBUTION BOXES; RENT A COLD STORAGEDELIVERY VEHICLE, AND REIMBURSE MILEAGE. FOR ACTIVITY NUMBER 2, FUNDSWILL BE USED TO PURCHASE HEALTHY, FROZEN MEALS FROM THAMES VALLEYCOALITION FOR COMMUNITY ACTION, INCORPORATED. THESE MEALS ARE DEVELOPEDIN CONNECTICUT AND USE CONNECTICUT GROWN INGREDIENTS. THESE FROZEN MEALSWILL BE DELIVERED TO OUR COMMUNITY CENTER WHERE STAFF WILL DELIVER THEMTO TRIBAL ELDERS (SENIORS) HOMES ON AND OFF THE RESERVATION. EACH ELDERHOUSEHOLD WILL GET 5 FROZEN MEALS AT DELIVERY EACH WEEK. EXPENSES ARECOST OF MEALS AND MILEAGE FEES. FOR ACTIVITY NUMBER 3, FUNDS WILL BEUSED TO PURCHASE VEGETABLES, FRUITS, DAIRY, MEATS FROM LOCAL FARMERS ANDUSED IN PREPARATION OF WEEKLY CONGREGATE MEALS FOR ELDERS BASED ON THENATIONAL DIETARY GUIDELINES. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BESUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDFARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS ASWELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDEPERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTEDBEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. PROJECT BENEFICIARIES WILL BEMASHANTUCKET PEQUOT TRIBAL NATION TRIBAL (SOCIALLY- ANDECONOMICALLY-DISADVANTAGED) FARMERS AND THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY IN GENERAL.BENEFITS TO THE FARM ARE INCREASED AND ENSURED REVENUE FOR PRODUCE WHICHEQUATES TO LESS FARM (FOOD) WASTE. BENEFITS TO THE TRIBAL COMMUNITYINCLUDE HEALTHIER EATING OPTIONS AND WITH THAT INCREASED HEALTHBENEFITS. FUNDS WILL BE USED TO MAKE FOOD PURCHASES FROM THEMASHANTUCKET PEQUOT TRIBAL NATION FARM, OTHER LOCAL AND TRIBAL FARMS,AND THAMES VALLEY COALITION FOR COMMUNITY ACTION, INCORPORATED.

THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCEFUNDING REQUESTED BY VERMONT AGENCY OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND MARKETSWILL ALSO HAVE IMPORTANT BENEFITS FOR LOCAL FARMERS AND FOOD PRODUCERS,ESPECIALLY THOSE THAT IDENTIFY AS PART OF A SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGEDGROUP. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND COMMERCE WILL PARTNER WITH THE THREE FEEDING AMERICA AFFILIATED FOOD BANKS THAT TOGETHER SERVICE ALL 82 COUNTIES IN THE STATE OF MISSISSIPPI. MISSISSIPPI DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND COMMERCE WILL SUBCONTRACT WITH EACH OF THE FOOD BANKS TO PROCURE LOCALLY PRODUCED FOOD, INCLUDING FOODS PURCHASED FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, AND DISTRIBUTE THE FOOD TO IDENTIFIED UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGH THEIR NETWORKS OF EXISTING AND NEW AGENCY PARTNERS CREATED AS A RESULT OF THE PROJECT. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. BENEFICIARIES OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE MISSISSIPPI'S SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, ADDITIONAL LOCAL FARMERS AND RANCHERS, PROCESSED FOOD PRODUCERS, AS WELL AS THE POPULATION IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. IT IS EXPECTED THAT FOOD PURCHASED FROM 30 FARMERS, FOOD PRODUCERS, AND COOPERATIVES WITH 33 PERCENT BEING SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED WILL BE DISTRIBUTED AT 50 LOCATIONS IN THE STATE. THE DOLLAR AMOUNT SUBCONTRACTED TO EACH OF THE FOOD BANKS WILL BE BASED UPON THEIR LEVEL OF FUNDING FOR THE EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAM IN THEIR SERVICE AREAS. THE FOOD BANKS WILL BOTH PROCURE AND DISTRIBUTE THE FOOD USING THEIR DELIVERY METHOD IN PLACE, OR THEY WILL SUBCONTRACT WITH A FOOD CONSOLIDATOR OR DISTRIBUTOR TO HANDLE THE PROCUREMENT AND DISTRIBUTION. THESE FOOD BANKS HAVE EXPERIENCE IN FOOD DISTRIBUTION, INCLUDING KNOWLEDGE OF FOOD SAFETY AND HANDLING, AND CAPACITY TO STORE AND MANAGE FOOD INVENTORY. THESE FOOD BANKS HAVE AN ESTABLISHED FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORK WORK WITH MULTIPLE PARTNER AGENCIES ACROSS THE STATE THAT ARE CURRENTLY ENGAGED IN FOOD DISTRIBUTION TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.

THE PROJECT PURPOSE IS TO FACILITATE AND INCREASE DIRECT-TO-MARKET SALES OF FOOD PRODUCTS GROWN BY DELAWARE FARMERS, TO DELAWARE COMMUNITY MEMBERS. OVER TWO YEARS, PROJECT PARTNERS AND COLLABORATORS WILL USE ONE-TIME FUNDS TO PILOT THE PURCHASE OF FRESH AND FROZEN FOODS FROM DELAWARE FARMERS AND A FROZEN FOOD PROCESSOR IN THE DELMARVA REGION, TO DEVELOP A LONG-TERM MODEL FOR STREAMLINED PROCUREMENT WITH COMMUNITY OUTLETS. THE PROJECT WILL 1) ESTABLISH A FARMER COOPERATIVE, FOCUSED ON MARKETING, PROMOTION TO MAXIMIZE CAPACITY OF SMALL, DISADVANTAGED FARMERS; 2) IDENTIFY EXISTING COMMUNITY OUTLETS PROVIDING FOOD ACCESS SPECIFICALLY TO UNDER-RESOURCED POPULATIONS WITH DEMONSTRATED FOOD INSECURITIES; AND 3) DEVELOP A MODEL ENABLING SMALL FARMERS AND COMMUNITY OUTLETS (ULTIMATELY RETAILERS AND OTHER MARKET INSTITUTIONS)TO ESTABLISH PROCUREMENT RELATIONSHIPS. PILOT PROJECT ALLOCATES FUNDS TO INCREASE PURCHASING POWER OF TWO EXISTING 'COMMUNITY OUTLETS' (FOOD DISTRIBUTION CHANNELS) TO PURCHASE DIRECTLY FROM FARMERS; CONNECT FARMERS, INCLUDING IN THE NEWLY FORMED COOPERATIVE WITH THE COMMUNITY OUTLETS LUTHERAN COMMUNITY SERVICES THROUGH THE DELAWARE FOOD FARMACY PROGRAM, SERVICING NEW CASTLE COUNTY; AND HISTORIC LEWES FARMERS MARKET THROUGH THE EPWORTH FOOD PANTRY SERVICING SUSSEX COUNTY. PARTNERS INCLUDE DELAWARE FARM BUREAU, TO DEVELOP A FARMER COOPERATIVE AND PROCUREMENT PLAN. COLLABORATORS INCLUDE LUTHERAN COMMUNITY SERVICES AND HISTORIC LEWES FARMERS, TO FACILITATE/AGGREGATE PURCHASES FROM FARMERS TO TRANSPORT TO FOOD PANTRIES FOR DISTRIBUTION TO COMMUNITIES IN NEED. THIS ESTABLISHES A REPLICABLE AND SCALABLE MODEL INCREASING THE NUMBER OF COMMUNITY OUTLETS WITHIN THE FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORK THAT SOURCE LOCAL FOODS AND NUMBER OF FARMERS THAT CAN FULFILL DEMANDS FOR LOCAL FOODS

THESE FUNDS WILL ALLOW US TOSUPPORT THE LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM IN PENNSYLVANIA BY PURCHASING FOOD FROMSMALL PRODUCERS AND PROCESSORS AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS WHOARE PRODUCING PENNSYLVANIA PRODUCT. BENEFICIARIES WILL BE TO WORK WITH INCREASING NUMBERS OF LOCALPRODUCERS, INCLUDING SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS/PRODUCERS AND VERYSMALL FARMERS WHOSE PRODUCTION CAPACITY CAN BE MATCHED WITH LOCALAGENCIES. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOODTARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE <(>&<)> CONSUMER SERVICES WILL AWARDSUB-GRANTS TO AGENCIES WITH THE CAPACITY TO PROCURE FOODS FROM LOCALSOURCES, FOCUSING ON SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS/VENDORS. THESUB-GRANTEES WILL COLLABORATE WITH FOOD DISTRIBUTION AGENCIES TODISTRIBUTE THESE PRODUCTS TO FOOD INSECURE INDIVIDUALS, FOCUSING ONSERVING SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED COMMUNITIES. MANY OF THE USDA FOODPROGRAMS LIKE THE EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAM, AND THE COMMODITYSUPPLEMENTAL FOOD PROGRAM ARE GREAT NUTRITION PROGRAMS, BUT THEY PROVIDEVERY LITTLE LOCALLY GROWN PRODUCTS. THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCEPROGRAM DOLLARS WILL ALLOW FOR A GREAT INCREASE IN THE AMOUNT OF LOCALFOODS THAT WILL WORK IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THESE EXISTING PROGRAMS TOPROVIDE A FULL RANGE OF FOODS FOR FAMILIES IN NEED. WE ESTIMATE THAT THEPROGRAM WILL PURCHASE FOOD FROM 166 LOCAL FARMERS AND THAT THE PROGRAMWILL DISTRIBUTE FOOD TO 164,000 INDIVIDUALS PER MONTH. VIRGINIA HAS ASTRONG NETWORK OF FOOD HUBS AND FOOD VENDORS ABLE TO MANAGE ALARGE-SCALE PROCUREMENT AND FOOD DISTRIBUTION OPERATION. VIRGINIA WILLREQUEST PROPOSALS FROM THESE ORGANIZATIONS AND AWARD SUB GRANTS. THESE ORGANIZATIONS WILL MANAGE THE GRANT FUNDS UNDER THE CLOSE GUIDANCE OF VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE <(>&<)> CONSUMER SERVICESSTAFF. VIRGINIA ALSO HAS A LARGE NETWORK OF FOOD BANKS THAT ARE ABLE TOCOLLABORATE WITH THE SUB-GRANTEES TO ASSIST WITH THE DISTRIBUTION OFFOOD BOXES. THE ALASKA LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE GRANT FUNDING FOR THE PURCHASE OF LOCALLY GROWN AND PRODUCED FOODS FROM FARMERS IN ALASKA. THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. BY PROVIDING AN INCOME SOURCE FOR ALASKA FARMERS THE FUNDS WILL STRENGTHEN REGIONAL FOOD SYSTEMS AND PROVIDE LOCAL FOODS TO DISADVANTAGED ALASKANS WHO HAVE LIMITED ACCESS TO LOCALLY SOURCED FOODS. THE ALASKA LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE PROGRAM WILL PARTNER WITH LOCAL FARMERS, VILLAGE AND TRIBAL FARMS, AND RANCHES.  IT WILL SUPPORT THE GROWTH OF REGIONAL FARMING THROUGH PILOT PROGRAMS WITH QIK'RTAQ FOOD HUB, WHICH INCLUDES SIX GEOGRAPHICALLY ISOLATED VILLAGES, AND STEVEN'S VILLAGE TRIBAL BUFFALO RANCH. STATEWIDE DEVELOPMENT OF COOPERATIVES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE FARM BUREAU WILL SUPPORT COORDINATION WITH THE ALASKA DIVISION OF AGRICULTURE FOR PROCUREMENT FOR THE FOOD BANK OF ALASKA IN PURCHASING FOODS AT COMPETITIVE ALASKA WHOLESALE PRICING.  ALASKA FARMERS MARKET ASSOCIATION WILL UTILIZE A PORTION OF THE GRANT FUNDS TO PURCHASE FOODS IN MARKETS ACROSS ALASKA. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. BENEFICIARIES ARE COMMUNITIES THAT DO NOT GEOGRAPHICALLY OR FINANCIALLY HAVE ACCESS TO LOCAL FRESH FOODS, NATIVE AMERICAN SMALL VILLAGES AND TRIBES, ELDER PROGRAMS, AND PARTNER FOOD BANKS. THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT INTEND TO SUBAWARD FUNDS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE AN ESTIMATED TWO MILLION POUNDS OF LOCAL PRODUCE, RICE, MEAT, AND SEAFOOD WHILE TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS. THE LOUISIANA DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY INTENDS TO EXPAND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL PRODUCERS, PARTICULARLY THOSE FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED AREAS, AND TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF LOCALLY GROWN ITEMS DISTRIBUTED TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING THEM WITH IMMEDIATE ECONOMIC SUPPORT THROUGH FOOD PURCHASES, WE WILL ALSO WORK TO STRENGTHEN CAPACITY, RESILIENCY, AND ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR LOCAL DISADVANTAGED GROWERS BY PROVIDING TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PROMOTE LONG TERM SUSTAINABILITY. THE GOALS OF THIS PROGRAM ARE TO DISTRIBUTE THE EQUIVALENT OF ONE MILLION, SIX HUNDRED THOUSAND MEALS’ WORTH OF LOCALLY GROWN AND PRODUCED FOOD TO APPROXIMATELY 130,000 PEOPLE WHILE AT THE SAME TIME PROVIDING SUPPORT TO TWO HUNDRED SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS WITH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE IN BOTH GROUP AND INDIVIDUALIZED SETTINGS TO MAKE THEIR FARMS OPERATIONALLY READY TO PARTICIPATE IN THIS PROGRAM AND EXPAND THEIR ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITIES DURING AND BEYOND THIS PROGRAM. METRICS WILL ALSO BE TRACKED ACROSS THE COURSE OF THE GRANT AND USED TO INFORM A TOOLKIT TO BE SHARED WITH OTHER STATES, NONPROFIT ORGANIZATIONS, AND FOOD BANKS WITH BEST PRACTICES FOR ENHANCING LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS BY CONNECTING LOCAL PRODUCERS AND LOW-INCOME NEIGHBORS. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCE REPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVED LOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. WE ANTICIPATE EXECUTING CONTRACTS WITH NINETY LOCAL PRODUCERS OF WHICH FORTY TO FORTY FIVE PERCENT BEING FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED BACKGROUNDS, WITH THE MAJORITY OF THOSE BEING SPECIALTY CROP FARMERS. PROCURED FOOD WILL SERVE APPROXIMATELY ONE HUNDRED THIRTY THOUSAND PEOPLE OVER THE COURSE OF THE GRANT PERIOD, ALL OF WHOM ARE FROM UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE RECIPIENT PLANS TO SUBAWARD FUNDS TO FEEDING LOUISIANA. AS A RESULT OF THE ADDITIONAL FUNDING AND EXTENDED PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE, THE NUMBER OF SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS PROVIDED WITH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO FACILITATE PARTICIPATION IN THE LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM WILL INCREASE FROM THE ORIGINAL ESTIMATE. THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO INCREASE THE AMOUNT OF LOCALLY GROWN AND PRODUCED FOOD PURCHASES, WHICH WILL BE DISTRIBUTED TO APPROXIMATELY 200,000 UNDERSERVED RECIPIENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCAL FOOD TARGETING PURCHASES FROM SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS.  THE PROJECT WILL BE LED BY THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF JOB AND FAMILY SERVICES, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE OHIO DEPARTMENTS OF AGRICULTURE AND EDUCATION AND WITH THE OHIO ASSOCIATION OF FOODBANKS. THE PROJECT WILL PARTNER WITH OHIO ASSOCIATION OF FOODBANKS TO EXPEND $11,700,000 TOWARD THE PURCHASE OF LOCALLY PRODUCED FOODS FROM AT LEAST 50 SUPPLIERS, AT LEAST FIFTY PERCENT OF WHOM WILL BE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED. FOOD DISTRIBUTION WILL FOCUS ON POPULATIONS UNDERSERVED BY TRADITIONAL FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS, INCLUDING RURAL HOUSEHOLDS, OLDER ADULTS, PEOPLE LIVING WITH DISABILITIES, AND DIASPORA CULTURES, AS WELL AS POPULATIONS EXPERIENCING OR AT-RISK OF CHRONIC, DIET-RELATED DISEASES THAT MAY NOT HAVE CONSISTENT ACCESS TO NUTRITIONALLY ADEQUATE FOODS. THE OHIO COMMUNITY AGRICULTURE AND NUTRITION PROJECT WILL PURCHASE FROM AT LEAST 50 LOCAL, REGIONAL FARMERS, GROWERS, PRODUCERS, OR OTHER VENDORS. AT LEAST HALF OF THOSE SUPPLIERS WILL BE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED. ALL PRODUCTS WILL BE ENTIRELY LOCALLY RAISED, GROWN, PRODUCED, SOURCED, AND MANUFACTURED. THE OHIO COMMUNITY AGRICULTURE AND NUTRITION PROJECT WILL PROVIDE FOODS TO FOOD INSECURE OHIOANS AT 200 PERCENT OR BELOW OF THE FEDERAL POVERTY LEVEL AND OTHERWISE UNDERSERVED BY TRADITIONAL FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. FOODS SOURCED WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT PROGRAM FUNDS WILL PROVIDE TAKE-HOME GROCERIES TO INCOME ELIGIBLE, UNDERSERVED OHIOANS AT LEAST 545,000 TIMES. PROVIDING ABOUT SIX DAYS OF MEALS PER PERSON, PER UNIT OF SERVICE, OR ABOUT 10 MILLION MEALS TOTAL. OHIO ASSOCIATION OF FOODBANKS WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THE OHIO DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE TO ENGAGE WITH LOCAL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, GROWERS, PRODUCERS, AND OTHER SUPPLIERS, INCLUDING THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN ONLINE RECRUITMENT TOOL AND THE CREATION OF A DATA TOOL THAT WILL TRACKENGAGEMENT WITH SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED AGRICULTURAL VENDORS. THE OHIO COMMUNITY AGRICULTURE AND NUTRITION PROJECT WILL BE ROOTED IN PROMOTING SUSTAINABILITY FOR LOCAL PRODUCERS AND ACCESS TO NEW MARKETS AND REVENUE SOURCES FOR SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS. OHIO ASSOCIATION OF FOODBANKS WILL STRIVE TO DISTRIBUTE 100 PERCENT OF PURCHASES OUTSIDE OF TRADITIONAL TEFAP DISTR IBUTION NETWORKS OR DISTRIBUTION MODELS OR TO POPULATIONS UNDERSERVED BY THE FOODS AVAILABLE THROUGH CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS OR WITH NUTRITIONAL NEEDS OR DIETARY PREFERENCES UNMET BY CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. 50 PERCENT OF THOSE DISTRIBUTION M ODELS ARE LIKELY TO BE SUSTAINED AFTER THE FUNDING IS EXPENDED. THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES SEEKS TO PURCHASEAND DISTRIBUTE LOCALLY GROWN, PRODUCED, AND PROCESSED FOOD FROM SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED FARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND BUSINESSES IN ORDER TO ADDRESSINJUSTICES INHERENT IN THE CURRENT FOOD SYSTEM. THROUGH A COLLABORATIVEREGIONAL MODEL, THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL RESOURCESWILL CONTRACT WITH MASSACHUSETTS FARMERS, FISHERIES, PRODUCERS, ANDDISTRIBUTORS THROUGH A COMPETITIVE BID PROCESS; DEVELOP AND DISSEMINATELOCALLY SOURCED AND PRODUCED FOOD TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; ANDCOLLECT DATA TO IDENTIFY, DEVELOP, AND MAINTAIN A COMPREHENSIVE DATABASEOF SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND MEMBERS OF THEMASSACHUSETTS FOOD SYSTEM TO CONDUCT OUTREACH AND MORE EFFECTIVELYENGAGE WITH THE STATE’S AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITY. QUARTERLY PERFORMANCEREPORTS WILL BE SUBMITTED TO CAPTURE THE NUMBER OF PRODUCERS, SOCIALLYDISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND RANCHERS, DISTRIBUTION SITES, AND UNDERSERVEDLOCATIONS AS WELL AS FUNDS EXPENDED FOR EACH CATEGORY. ANNUAL REPORTS WILL PROVIDE PERCENTAGES OF NEW MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES AND PURCHASES DISTRIBUTED BEYOND CURRENT FOOD DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS. TARGETAUDIENCES FOR THE PROJECT INCLUDE FARMERS, WITH SPECIAL CONSIDERATIONTO, BLACK, INDIGENOUS, PEOPLE OF COLOR, ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES, AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED POPULATIONS. THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES WILL PARTNER WITH ANDLEVERAGE THE KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE OF SERVICE PROVIDERS IN THE STATEAND REGIONAL NETWORK, INCLUDING NINE REGIONAL BUY LOCAL ORGANIZATIONS,COMMUNITY KITCHENS, FOOD BANKS AND PANTRIES, FOOD HUBS, AND EMERGENCYFOOD ORGANIZATIONS. THE EXPECTED REACH OF THE PROJECT WILL BE 100FARMERS, PRODUCERS, AND/OR BUSINESSES, OF WHICH AT LEAST 40 AREANTICIPATED TO BE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED, AND ADDITIONAL INTERESTEDPARTIES, WITH A DISTRIBUTION REACH OF APPROXIMATELY 100,000 INDIVIDUALS.THROUGH A COMPETITIVE REQUEST FOR RESPONSES PROCESS, THE MASSACHUSETTSDEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL RESOURCES WILL AWARD UP TO $4,354,000.00 INFUNDING TO SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, FOOD HUBS, EMERGENCY FOODNETWORK PARTNERS INCLUDING FOOD BANKS AND PANTRIES, NON-PROFITS, ANDORGANIZATIONS WITH THE CAPACITY TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE LOCALPRODUCTS ACROSS THE COMMONWEALTH. THOSE SUBRECIPIENTS WILL DIRECTLYDISTRIBUTE TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES AS IDENTIFIED BY AGENCY AND STATEPARTNERS, OR PARTNER WITH FOOD DISTRIBUTION PARTNERS TO ENSURE THAT AWIDE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION NETWORK IS ACHIEVED.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS AGREEMENT IS TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE $1,800,000 OF IOWA GROWN AND PRODUCED FOODS TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. THE GOAL IS TO BUILD A SUSTAINABLE PROGRAM TO INCREASE ACCESS TO LOCAL FOOD AND IMPROVE SUPPLY CHAIN RESILIENCY BY BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS WITH LOCAL PRODUCERS, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. TO ACCOMPLISH THIS, WE WILL PARTNER WITH IOWA VALLEY RESOURCE CONSERVATION AND DEVELOPMENT, PRACTICAL FARMERS OF IOWA, IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY EXTENSION AND OUTREACH, IOWA’S FOOD HUB MANGERS WORKING GROUP, IOWA FOOD BANKS ASSOCIATION, AND THE MESKWAKI NATION. IOWA IS EXPECTING THAT AT LEAST 300 FARMERS AND RANCHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE PROJECT, WITH A FOCUS ON SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS. THIS INCLUDES CREATION OF A TIERED EQUITABLE PURCHASING STANDARD. SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS WILL INCLUDE FARMERS OF COLOR, WOMEN FARMERS, REFUGEE AND IMMIGRANT FARMERS, LESBIAN, GAY, BISEXUAL, TRANSGENDER, QUEER FARMERS, AND VETERAN FARMERS.  OTHER BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THOSE ENTITIES RECEIVING PRODUCTS THROUGH DISTRIBUTION NETWORKS ACROSS ALL 99 COUNTIES IN IOWA.  TWO THOUSAND FOOD DISTRIBUTION SITES WILL BE ESTABLISHED WITH FOOD BANK CUSTOMERS, FOOD HUB DISTRIBUTION PARTNERS, AND THE MESKWAKI NATION. THE PROCUREMENT AND PURCHASING COMMITTEE WILL CONDUCT OUTREACH TO PRODUCERS, DEVELOP PRICE LISTS, PRODUCT STANDARDS AND APPROVE PRODUCERS FOR THE PROGRAM. THE EVALUATION AND FINANCIAL CONT ROLS COMMITTEE WILL DEVELOP SURVEYS, PRODUCER AND FOOD DISTRIBUTION PARTNER APPLICATION FORMS, AND A DATABASE TO MANAGE AND ORGANIZE ALL THE DATA. THE PROCUREMENT AND PURCHASING COMMITTEE WILL ASSIGN APPROVED PRODUCERS WITH FOOD HUBS AND FOOD BANKS AND ESTABLISHED PURCHASE AGREEMENTS. TO SUSTAIN THIS GROWTH AND CAPTURE THIS NEW OPPORTUNITY FOR IOWA, PROJECT PARTNERS WILL ESTABLISH A NEW COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE IN IOWA OF LOCAL FOOD PROCUREMENT PROFESSIONALS AT IOWA’S FOOD HUBS AND FOOD BANKS. THE COMMUNITY OF PRACTICE WILL CONSIST OF PROFESSIONALS THAT WORK AT IOWA’S FOOD HUBS AND FOOD BANKS THAT ALL HAVE THE GOAL OF SOURCING AND DISTRIBUTION OF IOWA GROWN AND MADE FOODS IN IOWA’S EMERGENCY FOOD ASSISTANCE PROGRAMS. THIS AWARD WILL RESULT IN SUBAWARDS TO EAT GREATER DES MOINES FOOD BANK, SOUTHEAST IOWA FOOD HUB, IOWA FOOD COOP FOOD HUB, FARM TABLE DELIVERY FOOD HUB, FIELD TO FAMILY FOOD HUB, GLOBAL GREENS FOOD HUB, GRINNELL FARM TO TABLE FOOD HUB, IOWA FOOD HUB ORGANIC GREENS FOOD HUB, PRUDENT PRODUCE FOOD HUB, ORGANIC GREENS FOOD HUB. THE SOVEREIGN NATION OF MESKWAKI LOCATED ON THE MESKWAKI SETTLEMENT IN TAMA COUNTY, IOWA, INCLUDES RED EARTH GARDENS WHO WORK TO ENSURE TRIBAL MEMBERS HAVE ACCESS TO FRESH, HEALTHY, CULTURALLY RELEVANT FOOD. IN FISCAL YEAR 2023, AGREEMENT WAS AMENDED WITH LOCAL FOOD PURCHASE ASSISTANCE PLUS FUNDING TO INCREASE THE BUDGET WITH FUNDS AUTHORIZED BY THE COMMODITY CREDIT CORPORATION, AND TO INCREASE THE DURATION OF THE PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE. AS A RESULT OF THE ADDITIONAL FUNDING AND EXTENDED PERIODOF PERFORMANCE, THE RECIPIENT INTENDS TO PROPOSE A THREE-YEAR PROJECT TO PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTE $4,160,086.70 OF IOWA GROWN AND PRODUCED FOODS TO UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.
